﻿CATRIONA

DEDICATION .

To [CHARLES BAXTER]169-charles baxter , [Writer to the Signet]399-writer to the signet .

[My]0-i Dear [Charles]170-prince charlie ,

It is the fate of sequels to disappoint those who have waited for [them]400-them ; and [[my]0-i David , having been left to kick [his]171-my david , having been left to kick his heels for more than a lustre in the british linen company s office heels for more than a lustre in [the British Linen Company s office]401-the british linen company s office]171-my david , having been left to kick his heels for more than a lustre in the british linen company s office , must expect [his]171-my david , having been left to kick his heels for more than a lustre in the british linen company s office late re - appearance to be greeted with hoots , if not with missiles . Yet , when [I]0-i remember the days of [our]402-our explorations , [I]0-i am not without hope . There should be left in [[our]402-our native city]403-our native city some seed of [the elect]404-the elect ; [some long - legged , hot - headed youth]405-some long - legged , hot - headed youth must repeat to - day [our]402-our dreams and wanderings of so many years ago ; [he]405-some long - legged , hot - headed youth will relish the pleasure , which should have been [ours]402-our , to follow among [named streets]406-named streets and [numbered houses]407-numbered houses [the country walks of [David Balfour]172-david balfour]408-the country walks of david balfour , to identify [Dean]14-dean , and [Silvermills]1-silvermills , and [Broughton]2-broughton , and [Hope Park]3-hope park , and [Pilrig]4-pilrig , and [poor old Lochend]5-poor old lochend if [it]409-it still be standing , and [the Figgate Whins]410-the figgate whins if there be any of [them]411-them left ; or to push on a long holiday so far afield as [Gillane]47-gillane or [the Bass]175-the bass . So , perhaps , [his]405-some long - legged , hot - headed youth eye shall be opened to behold the series of the generations , and [he]405-some long - legged , hot - headed youth shall weigh with surprise [his]405-some long - legged , hot - headed youth momentous and nugatory gift of life .

[You]412-you are still as when first [I]0-i saw , as when [I]0-i last addressed [you]412-you in [the venerable city which [I]0-i must always think of]413-the venerable city which i must always think of as [[my]0-i home]414-my home . And [I]0-i have come so far ; and the sights and thoughts of [[my]0-i youth]415-my youth pursue [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i see like a vision [the youth of [[my]0-i father]417-my father , and of [[his]405-some long - legged , hot - headed youth father]418-his father]416-the youth of my father , and of his father , and the whole stream of lives flowing down there far in [the north]419-the north , with the sound of laughter and tears , to cast [me]0-i out in the end , as by a sudden freshet , on [these ultimate islands]420-these ultimate islands . And [I]0-i admire and bow [my]0-i head before the romance of destiny .

R. L. S.

Vailima , [Upolu]6-upolu , [Samoa]7-samoa , 1892 .

CATRIONA Part [I]0-i [THE LORD ADVOCATE]421-the lord advocate

CHAPTER [I]0-i [A BEGGAR ON HORSEBACK]422-a beggar on horseback

The 25th day of August , 1751 , about two in the afternoon , [I]0-i , [David Balfour]172-david balfour , came forth of [the British Linen Company]423-the british linen company , [a porter]424-a porter attending [me]0-i with a bag of money , and [some of [the chief of [these merchants]427-these merchants]426-the chief of these merchants]425-some of the chief of these merchants bowing [me]0-i from [their]427-these merchants doors . Two days before , and even so late as yestermorning , [I]0-i was like [a beggar - man by the wayside , clad in rags]428-a beggar - man by the wayside , clad in rags , brought down to [my]0-i last shillings , [[my]0-i companion]429-my companion [a condemned traitor]430-a condemned traitor , a price set on [my]0-i own head for a crime with the news of which [the country]431-the country rang . To - day [I]0-i was served heir to [my]0-i position in life , [a landed laird]432-a landed laird , a bank porter by [me]0-i carrying [my]0-i gold , recommendations in [my]0-i pocket , and in the words of the saying the ball directly at [my]0-i foot .

There were two circumstances that served [me]0-i as ballast to so much sail . The first was the very difficult and deadly business [I]0-i had still to handle ; the second , the place that [I]0-i was in . [The tall , black city]433-the tall , black city , and the numbers and movement and noise of [so many folk]434-so many folk , made a new world for [me]0-i , after [the moorland braes]435-the moorland braes , [the sea - sands]436-the sea - sands and the still country - sides that [I]0-i had frequented up to then . [The throng of [the citizens in particular]438-the citizens in particular]437-the throng of the citizens in particular abashed [me]0-i . [[Rankeillor]176-rankeillor s son]439-rankeillor s son was short and small in the girth ; [his]439-rankeillor s son clothes scarce held on [me]0-i ; and it was plain [I]0-i was ill qualified to strut in the front of [a bank - porter]440-a bank - porter . It was plain , if [I]0-i did so , [I]0-i should but set [folk]441-folk laughing , and what was worse in [my]0-i case set [them]441-folk asking questions . So that [I]0-i behooved to come by some clothes of [my]0-i own , and in the meanwhile to walk by [the porter]442-the porter s side , and put [my]0-i hand on [his]442-the porter arm as though [we]443-we were a pair of [friends]444-friends .

At a merchant s in the Luckenbooths [I]0-i had [myself]0-i fitted out : none too fine , for [I]0-i had no idea to appear like [a beggar on horseback]422-a beggar on horseback ; but comely and responsible , so that [servants]446-servants should respect [me]0-i . Thence to [an armourer s]447-an armourer s , where [I]0-i got a plain sword , to suit with [my]0-i degree in life . [I]0-i felt safer with the weapon , though for [one so ignorant of defence it might be called an added danger]448-one so ignorant of defence it might be called an added danger . [The porter]442-the porter , who was naturally [a man of some experience]450-a man of some experience , judged [my]0-i accoutrement to be well chosen .

" [Naething kenspeckle]177-naething kenspeckle , "[442-the porter] 1 said [he]442-the porter ; " plain , [dacent claes]178-dacent claes . As for [the rapier]2943-the rapier , nae doubt it sits wi [your]0-i degree ; but an [I]442-the porter had been [you]0-i , [I]442-the porter would has waired [my]442-the porter siller better - gates than that . "[442-the porter] And [he]442-the porter proposed [I]0-i should buy winter - hosen from [a wife in [the Cowgate - back]452-the cowgate - back]451-a wife in the cowgate - back , that was [a cousin of [his]442-the porter own]453-a cousin of his own , and made [them]454-them " extraordinar endurable . "[442-the porter]

But [I]0-i had other matters on [my]0-i hand more pressing . Here [I]0-i was in [this old , black city]455-this old , black city , which was for [all the world]456-all the world like [a rabbit - warren]457-a rabbit - warren , not only by the number of [[its]455-this old , black city indwellers]458-its indwellers , but the complication of [its]455-this old , black city passages and holes . [It]455-this old , black city was , indeed , [a place where [no stranger]460-no stranger had a chance to find [a friend]461-a friend]459-a place where no stranger had a chance to find a friend , let be [another stranger]462-another stranger . Suppose [him]442-the porter even to hit on the right close , [people]463-people dwelt so thronged in [these tall houses]464-these tall houses , [he]442-the porter might very well seek a day before [he]442-the porter chanced on the right door . The ordinary course was to hire [a lad [they]466-they called a caddie , who was like [a guide or pilot]467-a guide or pilot , led [you]468-you where [you]468-you had occasion , and [your]468-you errands being done brought [you]468-you again where [you]468-you were lodging]465-a lad they called a caddie , who was like a guide or pilot , led you where you had occasion , and your errands being done brought you again where you were lodging . But [these caddies]469-these caddies , being always employed in the same sort of services , and having it for obligation to be well informed of [every house and person in [the city]471-the city]470-every house and person in the city , had grown to form [a brotherhood of spies]472-a brotherhood of spies ; and [I]0-i knew from tales of [Mr. Campbell]179-mr. campbell s how [they]469-these caddies communicated one with [another]473-another , what a rage of curiosity [they]469-these caddies conceived as to [[their]469-these caddies employer]474-their employer s business , and how [they]469-these caddies were like eyes and fingers to [the police]475-the police . It would be a piece of little wisdom , the way [I]0-i was now placed , to take such a ferret to [my]0-i tails . [I]0-i had three visits to make , all immediately needful : to [[my]0-i kinsman]476-my kinsman [Mr. Balfour of Pilrig]180-mr. balfour , to [[Stewart]181-james the Writer that was [Appin s agent]478-appin s agent , and to [[William Grant]182-prestongrange Esquire of [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange , Lord Advocate of [Scotland]182-prestongrange]182-prestongrange]477-stewart the writer that was appin s agent , and to william grant esquire of prestongrange , lord advocate of scotland . [Mr. Balfour]180-mr. balfour s was a non - committal visit ; and besides [Pilrig]180-mr. balfour being in [the country]431-the country [I]0-i made bold to find the way to it [myself]0-i , with the help of [my]0-i two legs and a Scots tongue . But the rest were in a different case . Not only was the visit to [[Appin]183-appin s agent]478-appin s agent , in the midst of the cry about the Appin murder , dangerous in itself , but it was highly inconsistent with the other . [I]0-i was like to have a bad enough time of it with [[my]0-i Lord Advocate Grant]481-my lord advocate grant , the best of ways ; but to go to [him]481-my lord advocate grant hot - foot from [Appin s agent]478-appin s agent , was little likely to mend [my]0-i own affairs , and might prove the mere ruin of [friend Alan]483-friend alan s. The whole thing , besides , gave [me]0-i a look of running with the hare and hunting with the hounds that was little to [my]0-i fancy . [I]0-i determined , therefore , to be done at once with [Mr. Stewart]184-mr. stewart and the whole Jacobitical side of [my]0-i business , and to profit for that purpose by the guidance of [the porter at [my]0-i side]484-the porter at my side . But it chanced [I]0-i had scarce given [him]184-mr. stewart the address , when there came a sprinkle of rain nothing to hurt , only for [my]0-i new clothes and [we]485-we took shelter under a pend at the head of [a close or alley]486-a close or alley .

Being strange to what [I]0-i saw , [I]0-i stepped a little farther in . The narrow paved way descended swiftly . [Prodigious tall houses]487-prodigious tall houses sprang upon each side and bulged out , one storey beyond another , as [they]487-prodigious tall houses rose . At the top only a ribbon of sky showed in . By what [I]0-i could spy in the windows , and by [the respectable persons that passed out and in]488-the respectable persons that passed out and in , [I]0-i saw [the houses]489-the houses to be very well occupied ; and the whole appearance of [the place]490-the place interested [me]0-i like a tale .

[I]0-i was still gazing , when there came a sudden brisk tramp of feet in time and clash of steel behind [me]0-i . Turning quickly , [I]0-i was aware of [a party of [armed soldiers]492-armed soldiers]491-a party of armed soldiers , and , in [their]491-a party of armed soldiers midst , [a tall man in a great coat]493-a tall man in a great coat . [He]493-a tall man in a great coat walked with a stoop that was like a piece of courtesy , genteel and insinuating : [he]493-a tall man in a great coat waved [his]493-a tall man in a great coat hands plausibly as [he]493-a tall man in a great coat went , and [his]493-a tall man in a great coat face was sly and handsome . [I]0-i thought [his]493-a tall man in a great coat eye took [me]0-i in , but could not meet it . [This procession]494-this procession went by to a door in the close , which [a serving - man in a fine livery set open]495-a serving - man in a fine livery set open ; and [two of [the soldier - lads]497-the soldier - lads]496-two of the soldier - lads carried [the prisoner]498-the prisoner within , the rest lingering with [their]496-two of the soldier - lads firelocks by the door .

There can nothing pass in [the streets of [a city]500-a city]499-the streets of a city without some following of [idle folk]501-idle folk and [children]502-children . It was so now ; but the more part melted away incontinent until but three were left . [One]503-one was [a girl]504-a girl ; [she]504-a girl was dressed like [a lady]505-a lady , and had a screen of the Drummond colours on [her]504-a girl head ; but [[her]504-a girl comrades]506-her comrades or [I]0-i should say followers were [ragged gillies]507-ragged gillies , such as [I]0-i had seen the matches of by the dozen in [my]0-i Highland journey . [They]508-they all spoke together earnestly in Gaelic , the sound of which was pleasant in [my]0-i ears for the sake of [Alan]185-alan ; and , though the rain was by again , and [[my]0-i porter]509-my porter plucked at [me]0-i to be going , [I]0-i even drew nearer where [they]508-they were , to listen . [The lady]510-the lady scolded sharply , [the others]511-the others making apologies and cringeing before [her]510-the lady , so that [I]0-i made sure [she]510-the lady was come of [[a chief]512-a chief s house]513-a chief s house . All the while [the three of [them]508-they]514-the three of them sought in [their]514-the three of them pockets , and by what [I]0-i could make out , [they]514-the three of them had the matter of half a farthing among [the party]515-the party ; which made [me]0-i smile a little to see [all Highland folk]516-all highland folk alike for fine obeisances and empty sporrans .

It chanced [the girl]517-the girl turned suddenly about , so that [I]0-i saw [her]517-the girl face for the first time . There is no greater wonder than the way the face of [a young woman]518-a young woman fits in [a man]519-a man s mind , and stays there , and [he]519-a man could never tell [you]520-you why ; it just seems it was the thing [he]519-a man wanted . [She]517-the girl had wonderful bright eyes like stars , and [I]0-i daresay the eyes had a part in it ; but what [I]0-i remember the most clearly was the way [her]517-the girl lips were a trifle open as [she]517-the girl turned . And , whatever was the cause , [I]0-i stood there staring like [a fool]521-a fool . On [her]517-the girl side , as [she]517-the girl had not known there was [anyone so near]522-anyone so near , [she]517-the girl looked at [me]0-i a little longer , and perhaps with more surprise , than was entirely civil .

It went through [my]0-i country head [she]517-the girl might be wondering at [my]0-i new clothes ; with that , [I]0-i blushed to [my]0-i hair , and at the sight of [my]0-i colouring it is to be supposed [she]517-the girl drew [her]517-the girl own conclusions , for [she]517-the girl moved [her]517-the girl gillies farther down the close , and they fell again to this dispute , where [I]0-i could hear no more of it .

[I]0-i had often admired [a lassie]523-a lassie before then , if scarce so sudden and strong ; and it was rather [my]0-i disposition to withdraw than to come forward , for [I]0-i was much in fear of mockery from [the womenkind]524-the womenkind . [You]525-you would have thought [I]0-i had now all the more reason to pursue [my]0-i common practice , since [I]0-i had met [this young lady in [the city street]527-the city street]526-this young lady in the city street , seemingly following [a prisoner]528-a prisoner , and accompanied with [two very ragged indecent - like Highlandmen]529-two very ragged indecent - like highlandmen . But there was here a different ingredient ; it was plain [the girl]517-the girl thought [I]0-i had been prying in [her]517-the girl secrets ; and with [my]0-i new clothes and sword , and at the top of [my]0-i new fortunes , this was more than [I]0-i could swallow . [The beggar on horseback]531-the beggar on horseback could not bear to be thrust down so low , or , at least of it , not by [this young lady]532-this young lady .

[I]0-i followed , accordingly , and took off [my]0-i new hat to [her]532-this young lady the best that [I]0-i was able .

" [Madam]2944-madam , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " [I]0-i think it only fair to [myself]0-i to let [you]2944-madam understand [I]0-i have no Gaelic . "[0-i]

CHAPTER II [THE HIGHLAND WRITER

Mr. Charles Stewart]184-mr. stewart [the Writer]547-the writer dwelt at the top of the longest stair ever mason set a hand to ; fifteen flights of it , no less ; and when [I]0-i had come to [his]547-the writer door , and [a clerk]548-a clerk had opened it , and told [me]0-i [[his]547-the writer master]549-his master was within , [I]0-i had scarce breath enough to send [[my]0-i porter]509-my porter packing .

" Awa east and west wi [ye]547-the writer ! "[0-i] said [I]0-i , took the money bag out of [his]547-the writer hands , and followed [the clerk]551-the clerk in .

[The outer room]552-the outer room was [an office with [the clerk]551-the clerk s chair at a table spread with law papers]553-an office with the clerk s chair at a table spread with law papers . In [the inner chamber]555-the inner chamber , which opened from [it]552-the outer room , [a little brisk man]556-a little brisk man sat poring on a deed , from which [he]556-a little brisk man scarce raised [his]556-a little brisk man eyes on [my]0-i entrance ; indeed , [he]556-a little brisk man still kept [his]556-a little brisk man finger in the place , as though prepared to show [me]0-i out and fall again to [his]556-a little brisk man studies . This pleased [me]0-i little enough ; and what pleased [me]0-i less , [I]0-i thought [the clerk]551-the clerk was in a good posture to overhear what should pass between [us]558-us .

[I]0-i asked if [he]556-a little brisk man was [Mr. Charles Stewart the Writer]199-stewart .

" The same , "[556-a little brisk man] says [he]556-a little brisk man ; " and , if the question is equally fair , who may [you]0-i be [yourself]0-i ? "[556-a little brisk man]

" [You]556-a little brisk man never heard tell of [my]0-i name nor of [me]0-i either , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " but [I]0-i bring [you]556-a little brisk man a token from [a friend that [you]556-a little brisk man know well]3019-a friend that you know well . That [you]556-a little brisk man know well , "[0-i] [I]0-i repeated , lowering [my]0-i voice , " but maybe are not just so keen to hear from at this present being . And the bits of business that [I]0-i have to propone to [you]556-a little brisk man are rather in the nature of being confidential . In short , [I]0-i would like to think [we]3020-we were quite private . "[0-i]

[He]556-a little brisk man rose without more words , casting down [his]556-a little brisk man paper like [a man]519-a man ill - pleased , sent forth [[his]556-a little brisk man clerk]560-his clerk of an errand , and shut to the house - door behind [him]556-a little brisk man .

" Now , [sir]3021-sir , "[556-a little brisk man] said [he]556-a little brisk man , returning , " speak out [your]3021-sir mind and fear nothing ; though before [you]3021-sir begin , "[556-a little brisk man] [he]556-a little brisk man cries out , " [I]556-a little brisk man tell [you]3021-sir [mine]556-a little brisk man misgives [me]556-a little brisk man ! A good name it is , and one it would ill - become [[my]556-a little brisk man father]417-my father s son to lightly . But [I]556-a little brisk man begin to grue at the sound of it . "[556-a little brisk man]

" [My]0-i name is called [Balfour]172-david balfour , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " [David Balfour of Shaws]172-david balfour . As for [him]561-i that sent [me]0-i , [I]0-i will let [his]561-i token speak . "[0-i] And [I]0-i showed the silver button .

" Put it in [your]0-i pocket , [sir]3021-sir ! "[561-i] cries [he]561-i . " [Ye]0-i need name no names . [The deevil s buckie]3026-the deevil s buckie , [I]561-i ken the button of [him]185-alan ! And de il hae t ! Where is [he]185-alan now ! "[561-i]

[I]0-i told [him]561-i [I]0-i knew not where [Alan]185-alan was , but [he]185-alan had some sure place or thought [he]185-alan had about [the north side]562-the north side , where [he]185-alan was to lie until [a ship]563-a ship was found for [him]185-alan ; and how and where [he]185-alan had appointed to be spoken with .

" It s been always [my]561-i opinion that [I]561-i would hang in a tow for [this family of mine]3027-this family of mine , "[561-i] [he]561-i cried , " and , dod ! " That is [my]0-i part of the affair , [Mr. Stewart]199-stewart , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " Here is a bag of good money , and if more be wanted , more is to be had where it came from . "[0-i]

" [I]561-i needn t ask [your]0-i politics , "[561-i] said [he]561-i .

" [Ye]0-i need not , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , smiling , " for [I]0-i m as big a Whig as grows . "[0-i]

" Stop a bit , stop a bit , "[199-stewart] says [Mr. Stewart]199-stewart . " What s all this ? [A Whig]3030-a whig ? Here is a forfeited rebel and [an accused murderer]3031-an accused murderer , with two hundred pounds on [his]185-alan life , and [ye]0-i ask [me]199-stewart to meddle in [his]185-alan business , and then tell [me]199-stewart [ye]0-i re [a Whig]3030-a whig ! [I]199-stewart have no mind of [any such Whigs]3033-any such whigs before , though [I]199-stewart ve kent plenty of [them]3033-any such whigs . "[199-stewart]

" [He]185-alan s [a forfeited rebel]3034-a forfeited rebel , the more s the pity , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " for [the man]3029-the man s [[my]0-i friend]3036-my friend . [I]0-i can only wish [he]3029-the man had been better guided . And [an accused murderer]3031-an accused murderer , that [he]3029-the man is too , for [his]3029-the man misfortune ; but wrongfully accused . "[0-i]

" [I]185-alan hear [you]185-alan say so , "[185-alan] said [Stewart]185-alan .

" More than [you]185-alan are to hear [me]0-i say so , before long , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " [Alan Breck]185-alan is innocent , and so is [James]181-james . "[0-i]

" Oh ! "[185-alan] says [he]185-alan , " the two cases hang together . If [Alan]185-alan is out , [James]181-james can never be in . "[185-alan]

Hereupon [I]0-i told [him]185-alan briefly of [my]0-i acquaintance with [Alan]185-alan , of the accident that brought [me]0-i present at the Appin murder , and the various passages of [our]564-our escape among the heather , and [my]0-i recovery of [my]0-i estate . " So , [sir]3021-sir , [you]3021-sir have now the whole train of these events , "[0-i] [I]0-i went on , " and can see for [yourself]3021-sir how [I]0-i come to be so much mingled up with the affairs of [[your]3021-sir family]3039-your family and [friends]444-friends , which for all of [our]564-our sakes [I]0-i wish had been plainer and less bloody . " [I]565-he have no great mind to it ; but coming as [you]0-i do with [Alan]185-alan s button , the choice is scarcely left [me]565-he , "[565-he] said [he]565-he . " What are [your]0-i instructions ? "[565-he] [he]565-he added , and took up [his]565-he pen .

" [I]185-alan am little likely to forget it , "[185-alan] said [Stewart]185-alan .

CHAPTER III [I]0-i GO TO [PILRIG]4-pilrig

The next morning , [I]0-i was no sooner awake in [[my]0-i new lodging]585-my new lodging than [I]0-i was up and into [my]0-i new clothes ; and no sooner the breakfast swallowed , than [I]0-i was forth on [[my]0-i adventurers]586-my adventurers . [Alan]185-alan , [I]0-i could hope , was fended for ; [James]181-james was like to be a more difficult affair , and [I]0-i could not but think that enterprise might cost [me]0-i dear , even as [everybody]587-everybody said to whom [I]0-i had opened [my]0-i opinion . It seemed [I]0-i was come to [the top of [the mountain]589-the mountain]588-the top of the mountain only to cast [myself]0-i down ; that [I]0-i had clambered up , through so many and hard trials , to be rich , to be recognised , to wear city clothes and a sword to [my]0-i side , all to commit mere suicide at the last end of it , and the worst kind of suicide , besides , which is to get hanged at [the King]590-the king s charges .

What was [I]0-i doing it for ? [I]0-i asked , as [I]0-i went down [the high Street]591-the high street and out north by [Leith Wynd]21-leith wynd . First [I]0-i said it was to save [James Stewart]181-james ; and no doubt the memory of [his]181-james distress , and [[his]181-james wife]2962-his wife s cries , and a word or so [I]0-i had let drop on that occasion worked upon [me]0-i strongly . At the same time [I]0-i reflected that it was or ought to be the most indifferent matter to [[[my]0-i father]417-my father s son]594-my father s son , whether [James]181-james died in [his]181-james bed or from a scaffold . [He]181-james was [[Alan]185-alan s cousin]595-alan s cousin , to be sure ; but so far as regarded [Alan]185-alan , the best thing would be to lie low , and let [the King]590-the king , and [his]590-the king Grace of [Argyll]22-argyll , and [the corbie crows]597-the corbie crows , pick the bones of [[his]590-the king kinsman]598-his kinsman [their]598-his kinsman own way . Nor could [I]0-i forget that , while [we]599-we were all in the pot together , [James]181-james had shown no such particular anxiety whether for [Alan]185-alan or [me]0-i .

Next it came upon [me]0-i [I]0-i was acting for the sake of justice : and [I]0-i thought that a fine word , and reasoned it out that since [we]599-we dwelt in polities , at some discomfort to [each one of [us]599-we]600-each one of us the main thing of all must still be justice , and the death of [any innocent man]601-any innocent man a wound upon [the whole community]602-the whole community . Next , again , it was [the Accuser of [the Brethren]217-the brethren]603-the accuser of the brethren that gave [me]0-i a turn of [his]603-the accuser of the brethren argument ; bade [me]0-i think shame for pretending [myself]0-i concerned in these high matters , and told [me]0-i [I]0-i was but [a prating vain child]604-a prating vain child , who had spoken big words to [Rankeillor]176-rankeillor and to [Stewart]181-james , and held [myself]0-i bound upon [my]0-i vanity to make good that boastfulness . Nay , and [he]603-the accuser of the brethren hit [me]0-i with the other end of the stick ; for [he]603-the accuser of the brethren accused [me]0-i of a kind of artful cowardice , going about at the expense of a little risk to purchase greater safety . No doubt , until [I]0-i had declared and cleared [myself]0-i , [I]0-i might any day encounter [Mungo Campbell]179-mr. campbell or [[the sheriff]605-the sheriff s officer]606-the sheriff s officer , and be recognised , and dragged into the Appin murder by the heels ; and , no doubt , in case [I]0-i could manage [my]0-i declaration with success , [I]0-i should breathe more free for ever after . But when [I]0-i looked this argument full in the face [I]0-i could see nothing to be ashamed of . As for the rest , " Here are [the two roads]3136-the two roads , "[0-i] [I]0-i thought , " and both go to the same place . It s unjust that [James]181-james should hang if [I]0-i can save [him]181-james ; and it would be ridiculous in [me]0-i to have talked so much and then do nothing . It s lucky for [James]181-james of the Glens that [I]0-i have boasted beforehand ; and none so unlucky for [myself]0-i , because now [I]0-i m committed to do right . [I]0-i have the name of [a gentleman]3137-a gentleman and the means of one ; it would be a poor duty that [I]0-i was wanting in the essence . "[0-i] And then [I]0-i thought this was [a Pagan spirit]607-a pagan spirit , and said a prayer in to [myself]0-i , asking for what courage [I]0-i might lack , and that [I]0-i might go straight to [my]0-i duty like [a soldier to battle]608-a soldier to battle , and come off again [scatheless]609-scatheless , as [so many]610-so many do .

This train of reasoning brought [me]0-i to a more resolved complexion ; though it was far from closing up [my]0-i sense of the dangers that surrounded [me]0-i , nor of how very apt [I]0-i was if [I]0-i went on to stumble on the ladder of the gallows . It was a plain , fair morning , but the wind in [the east]611-the east . The little chill of it sang in [my]0-i blood , and gave [me]0-i a feeling of the autumn , and the dead leaves , and [dead folks]612-dead folks bodies in [their]612-dead folks graves . It seemed [the devil]613-the devil was in it , if [I]0-i was to die in that tide of [my]0-i fortunes and for other folks affairs . On [the top of [the Calton Hill]23-the calton hill]614-the top of the calton hill , though it was not the customary time of year for that diversion , [some children]615-some children were crying and running with [their]615-some children kites . These toys appeared very plain against the sky ; [I]0-i remarked a great one soar on the wind to a high altitude and then plump among the whins ; and [I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i at sight of it , " There goes [Davie]172-david balfour . "[0-i]

[My]0-i way lay over [Mouter s Hill]24-mouter s hill , and through an end of a clachan on [the braeside among [fields]617-fields]616-the braeside among fields . There was a whirr of looms in it went from [house]618-house to [house]618-house ; bees bummed in [the gardens]620-the gardens ; [the neighbours that [I]0-i saw at the doorsteps]621-the neighbours that i saw at the doorsteps talked in a strange tongue ; and [I]0-i found out later that this was [Picardy]25-picardy , [a village where [the French weavers]623-the french weavers wrought for [the Linen Company]624-the linen company]622-a village where the french weavers wrought for the linen company . Here [I]0-i got a fresh direction for [Pilrig]4-pilrig , [my]0-i destination ; and a little beyond , on the wayside , came by a gibbet and [two men hanged in chains]625-two men hanged in chains . [They]625-two men hanged in chains were dipped in tar , as the manner is ; the wind span [them]625-two men hanged in chains , the chains clattered , and the birds hung about the uncanny jumping - jacks and cried . The sight coming on [me]0-i suddenly , like an illustration of [my]0-i fears , [I]0-i could scarce be done with examining it and drinking in discomfort . And , as [I]0-i thus turned and turned about the gibbet , what should [I]0-i strike on , but [a weird old wife , that sat behind a leg of it]626-a weird old wife , that sat behind a leg of it , and nodded , and talked aloud to [herself]626-a weird old wife , that sat behind a leg of it with becks and courtesies .

The two chance shots that seemed to point at [Alan]185-alan and [the daughter of [James More]181-james]628-the daughter of james more struck [me]0-i hard ; and [I]0-i fled from [the eldritch creature]629-the eldritch creature , casting [her]629-the eldritch creature a baubee , which [she]629-the eldritch creature continued to sit and play with under the moving shadows of the hanged .

[My]0-i way down [the causeway of [Leith Walk]26-leith walk]630-the causeway of leith walk would have been more pleasant to [me]0-i but for this encounter . [The old rampart]631-the old rampart ran among fields , the like of them [I]0-i had never seen for artfulness of agriculture ; [I]0-i was pleased , besides , to be so far in [the still countryside]632-the still countryside ; but the shackles of the gibbet clattered in [my]0-i head ; and the mope and mows of [the old witch]633-the old witch , and the thought of [the dead men]634-the dead men , hag - rode [my]0-i spirits . To hang on a gallows , that seemed a hard case ; and whether [a man]519-a man came to hang [there]636-there for two shillings [Scots]218-twa shillin scots , or as [Mr. Stewart]199-stewart had it from the sense of duty , once [he]519-a man was tarred and shackled and hung up , the difference seemed small . [I]0-i was thus in the poorest of spirits , though still pretty resolved , when [I]0-i came in view of [Pilrig]180-mr. balfour , [a pleasant gabled house set by the walkside among [some brave young woods]642-some brave young woods]641-a pleasant gabled house set by the walkside among some brave young woods . " [Pilrig]180-mr. balfour , August 26th , 1751 .[650-i]

" [[My]650-i Lord]3161-my lord , This is to bring to [your]0-i notice [[my]650-i namesake]3162-my namesake and cousin , [David Balfour Esquire of Shaws]172-david balfour , [a young gentleman of unblemished descent and good estate]3163-a young gentleman of unblemished descent and good estate . CHAPTER IV [LORD ADVOCATE PRESTONGRANGE]653-lord advocate prestongrange

[[My]0-i kinsman]476-my kinsman kept [me]0-i to a meal , " for the honour of the roof , "[653-lord advocate prestongrange] [he]653-lord advocate prestongrange said ; and [I]0-i believe [I]0-i made the better speed on [my]0-i return . [I]0-i had no thought but to be done with the next stage , and have [myself]0-i fully committed ; to [a person circumstanced as [I]0-i was]655-a person circumstanced as i was , the appearance of closing a door on hesitation and temptation was itself extremely tempting ; and [I]0-i was the more disappointed , when [I]0-i came to [[Prestongrange]182-prestongrange s house]656-prestongrange s house , to be informed [he]182-prestongrange was abroad . [I]0-i believe it was true at the moment , and for some hours after ; and then [I]0-i have no doubt [the Advocate]2990-the advocate came [home]658-home again , and enjoyed [himself]2990-the advocate in [a neighbouring chamber]659-a neighbouring chamber among [friends]444-friends , while perhaps the very fact of [my]0-i arrival was forgotten . [I]0-i would have gone away a dozen times , only for [this strong drawing]661-this strong drawing to have done with [my]0-i declaration out of hand and be able to lay [me]0-i down to sleep with a free conscience . At first [I]0-i read , for the little cabinet where [I]0-i was left contained a variety of books . But [I]0-i fear [I]0-i read with little profit ; and the weather falling cloudy , the dusk coming up earlier than usual , and [my]0-i cabinet being lighted with but a loophole of a window , [I]0-i was at last obliged to desist from this diversion such as it was , and pass the rest of [my]0-i time of waiting in a very burthensome vacuity . The sound of [people]463-people talking in [a near chamber]663-a near chamber , the pleasant note of a harpsichord , and once the voice of [a lady]505-a lady singing , bore [me]0-i a kind of company .

[I]0-i do not know the hour , but the darkness was long come , when the door of the cabinet opened , and [I]0-i was aware , by the light behind [him]665-he , of [a tall figure of a man upon the threshold]666-a tall figure of a man upon the threshold . [I]0-i rose at once .

" Is [anybody there]3171-anybody there ? "[665-he] [he]665-he asked . " Who in that ? "[665-he]

" [I]0-i am bearer of a letter from [the laird of [Pilrig]4-pilrig]3172-the laird of pilrig to [the Lord Advocate]421-the lord advocate , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" Have [you]0-i been [here]3174-here long ? "[665-he] [he]665-he asked .

" [I]0-i would not like to hazard an estimate of how many hours , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" It is the first [I]665-he hear of it , "[665-he] [he]665-he replied , with a chuckle . " [The lads]3175-the lads must have forgotten [you]0-i . But [you]0-i are in the bit at last , for [I]665-he am [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange . "[665-he]

So saying , [he]665-he passed before [me]0-i into [the next room]667-the next room , whither upon [his]665-he sign [I]0-i followed [him]665-he , and where [he]665-he lit a candle and took [his]665-he place before a business - table . It was [a long room]668-a long room , of a good proportion , wholly lined with books . That small spark of light in a corner struck out [[the man]3029-the man s handsome person]670-the man s handsome person and strong face . [He]3029-the man was flushed , [his]3029-the man eye watered and sparkled , and before [he]3029-the man sat down [I]0-i observed [him]3029-the man to sway back and forth . No doubt , [he]3029-the man had been supping liberally ; but [his]3029-the man mind and tongue were under full control .

" Well , [sir]3021-sir , sit [ye]3021-sir down , "[3029-the man] said [he]3029-the man , " and let [us]3177-us see [Pilrig]180-mr. balfour s letter . "[3029-the man]

[He]3029-the man glanced it through in the beginning carelessly , looking up and bowing when [he]3029-the man came to [my]0-i name ; but at the last words [I]0-i thought [I]0-i observed [his]3029-the man attention to redouble , and [I]0-i made sure [he]3029-the man read them twice . All this while [you]671-you are to suppose [my]0-i heart was beating , for [I]0-i had now crossed [my]0-i Rubicon and was come fairly on the field of battle .

If [they]204-the campbells do not get it if [this man James]3289-this man james escape there will be trouble with [the Campbells]204-the campbells . That means disturbance in [the Highlands , which are uneasy and very far from being disarmed]3290-the highlands , which are uneasy and very far from being disarmed : the disarming is a farce . . . "[182-prestongrange]

" [I]694-you can bear [you]3059-his lordship out in that , "[694-you] said [I.]694-you

" Disturbance in [the Highlands]29-the highlands makes the hour of [[our]3291-our old watchful enemy]3292-our old watchful enemy , "[3059-his lordship] pursued [[his]695-i lordship]3059-his lordship , holding out a finger as [he]695-i paced ; " and [I]695-i give [you]694-you [my]695-i word [we]3291-our may have a 45 again with [the Campbells]204-the campbells on the other side . To protect the life of [this man Stewart]3293-this man stewart which is forfeit already on half - a - dozen different counts if not on this do [you]694-you propose to plunge [your]694-you country in war , to jeopardise the faith of [[your]694-you fathers]3294-your fathers , and to expose the lives and fortunes of [how many thousand innocent persons]3295-how many thousand innocent persons ? . . . "[695-i]

" [You]694-you deal with [me]697-i very frankly , and [I]697-i thank [you]694-you for it , "[697-i] said [I.]697-i " [I]697-i will try on [my]697-i side to be no less honest . [I]697-i believe [your]694-you policy to be sound . [I]697-i believe these deep duties may lie upon [[your]694-you lordship]3164-your lordship ; [I]697-i believe [you]694-you may have laid them on [your]694-you conscience when [you]694-you took the oath of the high office which [you]694-you hold . But for [me]697-i , who am just [a plain man]3299-a plain man or scarce [a man yet the plain duties]3300-a man yet the plain duties must suffice . [I]697-i can think but of two things , of [a poor soul in the immediate and unjust danger of a shameful death]3301-a poor soul in the immediate and unjust danger of a shameful death , and of the cries and tears of [[his]3164-your lordship wife]2962-his wife that still tingle in [my]697-i head . [I]697-i can not see beyond , [[my]697-i lord]3161-my lord . It s the way that [I]697-i am made . If [the country]431-the country has to fall , it has to fall . And [I]697-i pray [God]223-god , if this be wilful blindness , that [He]698-he may enlighten [me]697-i before too late . "[697-i]

[He]698-he had heard [me]0-i motionless , and stood so a while longer .

" This is an unexpected obstacle , "[698-he] says [he]698-he , aloud , but to [himself]698-he .

" And how is [[your]698-he lordship]3164-your lordship to dispose of [me]0-i ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

CHAPTER V IN [THE ADVOCATE S HOUSE]700-the advocate s house

The next day , Sabbath , August 27th , [I]0-i had the occasion [I]0-i had long looked forward to , to hear [some of [the famous [Edinburgh]10-edinburgh preachers]702-the famous edinburgh preachers , all well known to [me]0-i already by the report of [Mr Campbell]179-mr. campbell]701-some of the famous edinburgh preachers , all well known to me already by the report of mr campbell . Alas ! and [I]0-i might just as well have been at [Essendean]30-essendean , and sitting under [[Mr. Campbell]179-mr. campbell s worthy self]703-mr. campbell s worthy self ! the turmoil of [my]0-i thoughts , which dwelt continually on the interview with [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange , inhibiting [me]0-i from all attention . [I]0-i was indeed much less impressed by the reasoning of [the divines]704-the divines than by the spectacle of the thronged congregation in [the churches]705-the churches , like what [I]0-i imagined of [a theatre]706-a theatre or in [my]0-i then disposition of an assize of trial ; above all at [the West Kirk]707-the west kirk , with [its]707-the west kirk three tiers of [galleries]708-galleries , where [I]0-i went in the vain hope that [I]0-i might see [Miss Drummond]193-miss drummond .

On the Monday [I]0-i betook [me]0-i for the first time to [a barber s]709-a barber s , and was very well pleased with the result . Thence to [the Advocate s]2991-the advocate s , where the red coats of [the soldiers]711-the soldiers showed again about [his]712-his door , making a bright place in the close . [I]0-i looked about for [the young lady]3012-the young lady and [[her]3012-the young lady gillies]714-her gillies : there was never a sign of [them]715-them . But [I]0-i was no sooner shown into the cabinet or antechamber where [I]0-i had spent so wearyful a time upon the Saturday , than [I]0-i was aware of the tall figure of [James More]181-james in a corner . [He]181-james seemed a prey to a painful uneasiness , reaching forth [his]181-james feet and hands , and [his]181-james eyes speeding here and there without rest about the walls of [the small chamber]716-the small chamber , which recalled to [me]0-i with a sense of pity [the man]3029-the man s wretched situation . [I]0-i suppose it was partly this , and partly [my]0-i strong continuing interest in [[his]181-james daughter]2999-his daughter , that moved [me]0-i to accost [him]181-james .

" Give [you]181-james a good - morning , [sir]3021-sir , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" All pass before [me]181-james , "[181-james] [he]181-james said , with a shrug and a gesture upward of the open hands . " It was not always so , [sir]3021-sir , but times change . There came a kind of Highland snuffle out of the man that raised [my]0-i dander strangely .

" That [you]181-james know not in the least , [sir]3021-sir , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " nor yet [anybody else]3323-anybody else ; but the name [I]0-i am called , if [you]181-james care to hear it , is [Balfour]180-mr. balfour . "[0-i]

" In the year [you]181-james refer to , [Mr. Macgregor]232-mr. macgregor , [I]0-i was getting skelped in [the parish school]3337-the parish school , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" So young ! "[181-james] cries [he]181-james . " Ah , then , [you]0-i will never be able to think what this meeting is to [me]721-my . [Sir]3021-sir , this is a sad look back that many of [us]3342-us have to make : some with falling tears . [I]721-my have lived in [[my]721-my own country]3343-my own country like [a king]2948-a king ; [my]721-my sword , [my]721-my mountains , and the faith of [[my]721-my friends]3075-my friends and [kinsmen]3346-kinsmen sufficed for [me]721-my . [I]0-i would be ashamed to set down all [he]722-him poured out to [me]0-i in this beggarly vein , or the very short and grudging answers that [I]0-i made to [him]722-him . And [I]0-i was still being wheedled and preached to , and still being marched to and fro , three steps and a turn , in [that small chamber]726-that small chamber , and had already , by some very short replies , highly incensed , although not finally discouraged , [[my]0-i beggar]727-my beggar , when [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange appeared in the doorway and bade [me]0-i eagerly into [[his]182-prestongrange big chamber]728-his big chamber .

Hereupon [all three]733-all three , and [the old Miss Grant]234-miss grant as well , cried out against this sally , which as [I]0-i was acquainted with the verses [he]182-prestongrange referred to brought shame into [my]0-i own check . It seemed to [me]0-i a citation unpardonable in [a father]734-a father , and [I]0-i was amazed that [these ladies]735-these ladies could laugh even while [they]735-these ladies reproved , or made believe to .

Under cover of this mirth , [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange got forth of [the chamber]736-the chamber , and [I]0-i was left , like a fish upon [dry land]737-dry land , in that very unsuitable society . [I]0-i could never deny , in looking back upon what followed , that [I]0-i was eminently stockish ; and [I]0-i must say [the ladies]738-the ladies were well drilled to have so long a patience with [me]0-i . [The aunt]739-the aunt indeed sat close at [her]739-the aunt embroidery , only looking now and again and smiling ; but [the misses]740-the misses , and especially [the eldest , who was besides the most handsome]741-the eldest , who was besides the most handsome , paid [me]0-i a score of attentions which [I]0-i was very ill able to repay . It was all in vain to tell [myself]0-i [I]0-i was [a young follow of some worth as well as a good estate]742-a young follow of some worth as well as a good estate , and had no call to feel abashed before [these lasses]743-these lasses , [the eldest]744-the eldest not so much older than [myself]0-i , and [no one of them by any probability half as learned]745-no one of them by any probability half as learned . Reasoning would not change the fact ; and there were times when the colour came into [my]0-i face to think [I]0-i was shaved that day for the first time .

The talk going , with all [their]743-these lasses endeavours , very heavily , [the eldest]744-the eldest took pity on [my]0-i awkwardness , sat down to [her]744-the eldest instrument , of which [she]744-the eldest was [a passed mistress]747-a passed mistress , and entertained [me]0-i for a while with playing and singing , both in the Scots and in the Italian manners ; this put [me]0-i more at [my]0-i ease , and being reminded of [Alan]235-alan s air that [he]235-alan had taught [me]0-i in [the hole near [Carriden]31-carriden]748-the hole near carriden , [I]0-i made so bold as to whistle a bar or two , and ask if [she]744-the eldest knew that .

[She]744-the eldest shook [her]744-the eldest head . " [I]744-the eldest never heard a note of it , "[744-the eldest] said [she]744-the eldest . " Whistle it all through . And now once again , "[744-the eldest] [she]744-the eldest added , after [I]0-i had done so .

Then [she]744-the eldest picked it out upon the keyboard , and to [my]0-i surprise instantly enriched the same with well - sounding chords , and sang , as [she]744-the eldest played , with a very droll expression and broad accent

" Haenae [I]744-the eldest got just the lilt of it ? Isnae this the tune that [ye]0-i whustled ? "[744-the eldest]

" [You]0-i see , "[744-the eldest] [she]744-the eldest says , " [I]744-the eldest can do the poetry too , only it won t rhyme . And then again :[744-the eldest]

" [I]0-i do not know the real name , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " [I]0-i just call it [Alan]235-alan s air . "[0-i]

" [I]744-the eldest shall call it [David]222-davie s air , "[744-the eldest] said [she]744-the eldest ; " though if it s the least like what [[your]0-i namesake of [Israel]237-israel]3361-your namesake of israel played to [Saul]238-saul [I]744-the eldest would never wonder that [the king]590-the king got little good by it , for it s but melancholy music . This was said with a significance that gave [my]0-i heart a jog . " Why that , [Miss Grant]234-miss grant ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" Why , "[744-the eldest] says [she]744-the eldest , " if ever [you]0-i should come to get hanged , [I]744-the eldest will set [your]0-i last dying speech and confession to that tune and sing it . "[744-the eldest]

This put it beyond a doubt that [she]744-the eldest was partly informed of [my]0-i story and peril . How , or just how much , it was more difficult to guess . It was plain [she]744-the eldest knew there was something of danger in the name of [Alan]235-alan , and thus warned [me]0-i to leave it out of reference ; and plain [she]744-the eldest knew that [I]0-i stood under some criminal suspicion . [I]0-i judged besides that the harshness of [her]744-the eldest last speech which besides [she]744-the eldest had followed up immediately with a very noisy piece of music was to put an end to the present conversation . [I]0-i stood beside [her]744-the eldest , affecting to listen and admire , but truly whirled away by [my]0-i own thoughts . [I]0-i have always found [this young lady]532-this young lady to be [a lover of the mysterious]750-a lover of the mysterious ; and certainly this first interview made a mystery that was beyond [my]0-i plummet . One thing [I]0-i learned long after , the hours of the Sunday had been well employed , [the bank porter]751-the bank porter had been found and examined , [my]0-i visit to [Charles Stewart]199-stewart was discovered , and the deduction made that [I]0-i was pretty deep with [James]181-james and [Alan]235-alan , and most likely in a continued correspondence with [the last]752-the last . Hence this broad hint that was given [me]0-i across the harpsichord .

In the midst of the piece of music , one of [the younger misses , who was at a window over the close]753-the younger misses , who was at a window over the close , cried on [[her]744-the eldest sisters]754-her sisters to come quick , for there was " Grey eyes again . "[755-the whole family] [The whole family]755-the whole family trooped [there]636-there at once , and crowded [one another]757-one another for a look . The window whither [they]755-the whole family ran was in an odd corner of [that room]758-that room , gave above the entrance door , and flanked up the close .

" Come , [Mr. Balfour]222-davie , "[755-the whole family] [they]755-the whole family cried , " come and see . [She]759-she is [the most beautiful creature]3363-the most beautiful creature ! [She]759-she hangs round the close - head these last days , always with [some wretched - like gillies]3364-some wretched - like gillies , and yet seems quite [a lady]505-a lady . "[755-the whole family]

[I]0-i had no need to look ; neither did [I]0-i look twice , or long . [I]0-i was afraid [she]759-she might have seen [me]0-i there , looking down upon [her]759-she from that chamber of music , and [she]759-she without , and [[her]759-she father]760-her father in [the same house]761-the same house , perhaps begging for [his]760-her father life with tears , and [myself]0-i come but newly from rejecting [his]760-her father petitions . But even that glance set [me]0-i in a better conceit of [myself]0-i and much less awe of [the young ladies]762-the young ladies . [They]762-the young ladies were beautiful , that was beyond question , but [Catriona]189-catriona was beautiful too , and had a kind of brightness in [her]189-catriona like a coal of fire . As much as [the others]511-the others cast [me]0-i down , [she]759-she lifted [me]0-i up . [I]0-i remembered [I]0-i had talked easily with [her]759-she . " Now , [girls]3366-girls , "[3356-papa] said [he]3356-papa , " [I]3356-papa must take [Mr. Balfour]222-davie away again ; but [I]3356-papa hope [you]3366-girls have been able to persuade [him]222-davie to return where [I]3356-papa shall be always gratified to find [him]222-davie . "[3356-papa]

[I]0-i began to walk swiftly and at random , conscious only of a desire for movement , air , and [the open country]825-the open country .

CHAPTER VII [I]0-i MAKE A FAULT IN HONOUR

[I]0-i came forth , [I]0-i vow [I]0-i know not how , on [the Lang Dykes 12]826-the lang dykes 12 . This is [a rural road]827-a rural road which runs on the north side over against [the city]471-the city . Thence [I]0-i could see the whole black length of [it]827-a rural road tail down , from where [the castle]3106-the castle stands upon [[its]3106-the castle crags above [the loch]831-the loch]830-its crags above the loch in a long line of spires and gable ends , and smoking chimneys , and at the sight [my]0-i heart swelled in [my]0-i bosom . [My]0-i youth , as [I]0-i have told , was already inured to dangers ; but such danger as [I]0-i had seen the face of but that morning , in the midst of what [they]832-they call the safety of [a town]833-a town , shook [me]0-i beyond experience . Peril of slavery , peril of shipwreck , peril of sword and shot , [I]0-i had stood all of these without discredit ; but the peril there was in the sharp voice and the fat face of [Simon]240-mr. simon , properly [Lord Lovat]243-lovat , daunted [me]0-i wholly .

[I]0-i sat by [the lake]834-the lake side in [a place where the rushes went down into [the water]3088-the water]835-a place where the rushes went down into the water , and there steeped [my]0-i wrists and laved [my]0-i temples . If [I]0-i could have done so with any remains of self - esteem , [I]0-i would now have fled from [my]0-i foolhardy enterprise . But call it courage or cowardice , and [I]0-i believe it was both [the one and the other]837-the one and the other [I]0-i decided [I]0-i was ventured out beyond the possibility of a retreat . [I]0-i had out - faced [these men]838-these men , [I]0-i would continue to out - face [them]838-these men ; come what might , [I]0-i would stand by the word spoken .

The sense of [my]0-i own constancy somewhat uplifted [my]0-i spirits , but not much . At the best of it there was an icy place about [my]0-i heart , and life seemed a black business to be at all engaged in . For [two souls in particular]839-two souls in particular [my]0-i pity flowed . [The one]3002-the one was [myself]0-i , to be so friendless and lost among dangers . [The other]3003-the other was [the girl]517-the girl , [the daughter of [James More]181-james]628-the daughter of james more . [I]0-i had seen but little of [her]517-the girl ; yet [my]0-i view was taken and [my]0-i judgment made . [I]0-i reflected it was hard [I]0-i should be so plagued and persecuted all [my]0-i days for other folks affairs , and have no manner of pleasure [myself]0-i . [I]0-i got meals and a bed to sleep in when [my]0-i concerns would suffer it ; beyond that [my]0-i wealth was of no help to [me]0-i . If [I]0-i was to hang , [my]0-i days were like to be short ; if [I]0-i was not to hang but to escape out of this trouble , [they]851-they might yet seem long to [me]0-i ere [I]0-i was done with [them]851-they . CHAPTER VIII THE BRAVO

[[My]0-i three keepers]918-my three keepers led [me]0-i out by [Bristo]253-bristo and [the Bruntsfield Links]919-the bruntsfield links ; whence [a path]920-a path carried [us]916-we to [Hope Park]3-hope park , [a beautiful pleasance , laid with gravel - walks]921-a beautiful pleasance , laid with gravel - walks , furnished with seats and [summer - sheds]922-summer - sheds , and warded by [a keeper]923-a keeper . [Some of [the advocates set up to be wits]935-the advocates set up to be wits]934-some of the advocates set up to be wits , and [some of [the soldiers]711-the soldiers]936-some of the soldiers to be rattles ; and [I]0-i could not tell which of these extremes annoyed [me]0-i most . " No , "[941-one of the officers] says [he]941-one of the officers , " but [I]941-one of the officers wass thinking . "[941-one of the officers]

" [I]0-i would not advise [you]941-one of the officers to make a practice of that , [sir]3021-sir , "[0-i] says [I.]0-i " [I]0-i feel sure [you]941-one of the officers would not find it to agree with [you]941-one of the officers . "[0-i]

" Tit [you]0-i effer hear where [Alan Grigor]185-alan fand the tangs ? "[941-one of the officers] said [he]941-one of the officers .

[I]0-i asked [him]941-one of the officers what [he]941-one of the officers could possibly mean , and [he]941-one of the officers answered , with a heckling laugh , that [he]941-one of the officers thought [I]0-i must have found the poker in the same place and swallowed it .

There could be no mistake about this , and [my]0-i cheek burned .

" Before [I]0-i went about to put affronts on [gentlemen]3557-gentlemen , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " [I]0-i think [I]0-i would learn the English language first . "[0-i]

[He]941-one of the officers took [me]0-i by the sleeve with a nod and a wink and led [me]0-i quietly outside [Hope Park]3-hope park . " Enough plows [I]941-one of the officers think , "[941-one of the officers] says [he]941-one of the officers . [I]0-i returned [his]941-one of the officers bow , told [him]941-one of the officers to go first , and followed [him]941-one of the officers . As [he]941-one of the officers went [I]0-i heard [him]941-one of the officers grumble to [himself]941-one of the officers about Cot s English and the King s coat , so that [I]0-i might have supposed [him]941-one of the officers to be seriously offended . But [his]941-one of the officers manner at the beginning of [our]947-our interview was there to belie [him]941-one of the officers . It was manifest [he]941-one of the officers had come prepared to fasten a quarrel on [me]0-i , right or wrong ; manifest that [I]0-i was taken in a fresh contrivance of [[my]0-i enemies]3321-my enemies ; and to [me]0-i conscious as [I]0-i was of [my]0-i deficiencies manifest enough that [I]0-i should be the one to fall in [our]947-our encounter .

As [we]947-our came into [that rough rocky desert of [the King s Park]3564-the king s park]949-that rough rocky desert of the king s park [I]0-i was tempted half - a - dozen times to take to [my]0-i heels and run for it , so loath was [I]0-i to show [my]0-i ignorance in fencing , and so much averse to die or even to be wounded . But [I]0-i considered if [their]951-their malice went as far as this , it would likely stick at nothing ; and that to fall by the sword , however ungracefully , was still an improvement on the gallows . [I]0-i considered besides that by the unguarded pertness of [my]0-i words and the quickness of [my]0-i blow [I]0-i had put [myself]0-i quite out of court ; and that even if [I]0-i ran , [[my]0-i adversary]952-my adversary would probably pursue and catch [me]0-i , which would add disgrace to [my]0-i misfortune . So that , taking all in all , [I]0-i continued marching behind [him]952-my adversary , much as [a man]519-a man follows [the hangman]954-the hangman , and certainly with no more hope .

[We]955-we went about the end of [the long craigs]956-the long craigs , and came into the [Hunter s Bog]41-hunter s bog . Here , on [a piece of fair turf]957-a piece of fair turf , [[my]0-i adversary]952-my adversary drew . There was [nobody there]959-nobody there to see [us]955-we but some birds ; and no resource for [me]0-i but to follow [his]952-my adversary example , and stand on guard with the best face [I]0-i could display . It seems it was not good enough for [Mr. Dancansby]257-mr. dancansby , who spied some flaw in [my]0-i manouvres , paused , looked upon [me]0-i sharply , and came off and on , and menaced [me]0-i with [his]952-my adversary blade in the air . As [I]0-i had seen no such proceedings from [Alan]185-alan , and was besides a good deal affected with the proximity of death , [I]0-i grew quite bewildered , stood helpless , and could have longed to run away .

" Fat deil ails [her]3565-her ? "[960-the lieutenant] cries [the lieutenant]960-the lieutenant .

And suddenly engaging , [he]960-the lieutenant twitched the sword out of [my]0-i grasp and sent it flying far among the rushes .

CHAPTER IX [THE HEATHER ON FIRE]991-the heather on fire

When [I]0-i left [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange that afternoon [I]0-i was for the first time angry . [The Advocate]2990-the advocate had made a mock of [me]0-i . [He]2990-the advocate had pretended [my]0-i testimony was to be received and [myself]0-i respected ; and in that very hour , not only was [Simon]240-mr. simon practising against [my]0-i life by the hands of [the Highland soldier]993-the highland soldier , but as appeared from [his]182-prestongrange own language [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange [himself]182-prestongrange had some design in operation . [I]0-i counted [[my]0-i enemies]3321-my enemies ; [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange with all [the King]590-the king s authority behind [him]182-prestongrange ; and [the Duke]3273-the duke with the power of the [West Highlands]46-west highlands ; and [the Lovat]243-lovat interest by [their]997-their side to help [them]997-their with so great a force in [the north]419-the north , and [the whole clan of [old Jacobite spies]1000-old jacobite spies and [traffickers]1001-traffickers]999-the whole clan of old jacobite spies and traffickers . And when [I]0-i remembered [James More]181-james , and [the red head of Neil [the son of [Duncan]186-duncan]917-the son of duncan]1002-the red head of neil the son of duncan , [I]0-i thought there was perhaps a fourth in the confederacy , and what remained of [[Rob Roy]262-robin s old desperate sept of [caterans]1005-caterans]1004-rob roy s old desperate sept of caterans would be banded against [me]0-i with the others . One thing was requisite [some strong friend]1006-some strong friend or [wise adviser]1007-wise adviser . [The country]431-the country must be full of such , both able and eager to support [me]0-i , or [Lovat]243-lovat and [the Duke]3273-the duke and [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange had not been nosing for expedients ; and it made [me]0-i rage to think that [I]0-i might brush against [[my]0-i champions]1010-my champions in [the street]3016-the street and be no wiser .

And just then like an answer [a gentleman]3137-a gentleman brushed against [me]0-i going by , gave [me]0-i a meaning look , and turned into a close . [I]0-i knew [him]182-prestongrange with the tail of [my]0-i eye it was [Stewart the Writer]199-stewart ; and , blessing [my]0-i good fortune , turned in to follow [him]182-prestongrange . As soon as [I]0-i had entered the close [I]0-i saw [him]182-prestongrange standing in the mouth of a stair , where [he]182-prestongrange made [me]0-i a signal and immediately vanished . Seven storeys up , there [he]182-prestongrange was again in [a house]1013-a house door , the which [he]182-prestongrange looked behind [us]1014-we after [we]1014-we had entered . [The house]818-the house was quite dismantled , with not a stick of furniture ; indeed , [it]1016-it was one of which [Stewart]199-stewart had the letting in [his]199-stewart hands .

" [We]1014-we ll have to sit upon the floor , "[199-stewart] said [he]199-stewart ; " but [we]1014-we re safe [here]3174-here for the time being , and [I]199-stewart ve been wearying to see [ye]0-i , [Mr. Balfour]222-davie . "[199-stewart]

" How s it with [Alan]185-alan ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" [Brawly]263-brawly , "[199-stewart] said [he]199-stewart . " [Andie]213-andie picks [him]185-alan up at [Gillane]47-gillane sands to - morrow , Wednesday . And that brings [me]199-stewart to the essential : how does [your]0-i business speed ? "[199-stewart]

" Why , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " [I]0-i was told only this morning that [my]0-i testimony was accepted , and [I]0-i was to travel to [Inverary]39-inverary with [the Advocate]2990-the advocate , no less . "[0-i]

" [I]0-i have maybe a suspicion of [my]0-i own , "[0-i] says [I]0-i , " but [I]0-i would like fine to hear [your]199-stewart reasons . "[0-i]

" Well , [I]199-stewart tell [ye]0-i fairly , [I]199-stewart m horn - mad , "[199-stewart] cries [Stewart]199-stewart . " If [my]199-stewart one hand could pull [their]3601-they Government down [I]199-stewart would pluck it like a rotten apple . "[199-stewart]

" And how are [they]3601-they to bring in [Alan]185-alan till [they]3601-they can catch [him]185-alan ? "[1017-i] says [I.]1017-i

" Ah , but there is a way to evite that arrestment , "[1017-i] said [he]1017-i . " Sound law , too . It would be a bonny thing if , by the escape of [one ill - doer another]3606-one ill - doer another was to go scatheless , and [the remeid]3607-the remeid is to summon [the principal]3608-the principal and put [him]3608-the principal to outlawry for the non - compearance . Now there s four places where [a person]3609-a person can be summoned : at [[his]3609-a person dwelling - house]3610-his dwelling - house ; at a place where [he]3609-a person has resided forty days ; at [the head burgh of [the shire]3612-the shire]3611-the head burgh of the shire where [he]3609-a person ordinarily resorts ; or lastly if there be ground to think [him]3609-a person forth of [Scotland]182-prestongrange at [the cross of [Edinburgh]10-edinburgh]3613-the cross of edinburgh , and [the pier and shore of [Leith]49-leith]3614-the pier and shore of leith , for sixty days . The purpose of which last provision is evident upon its face : being that [outgoing ships]3615-outgoing ships may have time to carry news of the transaction , and the summonsing be something other than a form . Now take the case of [Alan]185-alan . [He]185-alan has [no dwelling - house]3616-no dwelling - house that ever [I]1017-i could hear of ; [I]1017-i would be obliged if [anyone]3224-anyone would show [me]1017-i where [he]185-alan has lived forty days together since the 45 ; there is no shire where [he]185-alan resorts whether ordinarily or extraordinarily ; if [he]185-alan has a domicile at all , which [I]1017-i misdoubt , it must be with [his]185-alan regiment in [France]50-france ; and if [he]185-alan is not yet forth of [Scotland]182-prestongrange as [we]3618-we happen to know and [they]3618-we happen to guess it must be evident to [the most dull]3619-the most dull it s what [he]185-alan s aiming for . Where , then , and what way should [he]185-alan be summoned ? [I]1017-i ask it at [yourself]1018-ye , [a layman]3620-a layman . "[1017-i]

" [You]1018-ye have given the very words , "[1018-ye] said [I.]1018-ye " Here at the cross , and at [the pier and shore of [Leith]49-leith]3614-the pier and shore of leith , for sixty days . "[1018-ye]

" [Ye]1018-ye re a sounder Scots lawyer than [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange , then ! "[547-the writer] cries [the Writer]547-the writer . " [He]185-alan has had [Alan]185-alan summoned once ; that was on the twenty - fifth , the day that [we]3618-we first met . Once , and done with it . And where ? Where , but at [the cross of [Inverary]39-inverary]3622-the cross of inverary , [the head burgh of [the Campbells]204-the campbells]3623-the head burgh of the campbells ? A word in [your]1018-ye ear , [Mr. Balfour]222-davie [they]3624-they re not seeking [Alan]185-alan . "[547-the writer]

CHAPTER X THE RED - HEADED MAN

It was about half - past three when [I]0-i came forth on [the Lang Dykes]3687-the lang dykes . [Dean]14-dean was where [I]0-i wanted to go . Since [Catriona]189-catriona dwelled [there]636-there , and [her]189-catriona kinsfolk [the Glengyle Macgregors]190-the glengyle macgregors appeared almost certainly to be employed against [me]0-i , it was just one of [the few places [I]0-i should have kept away from]1035-the few places i should have kept away from ; and being [a very young man]1036-a very young man , and beginning to be very much in love , [I]0-i turned [my]0-i face in that direction without pause . As a slave to [my]0-i conscience and common sense , however , [I]0-i took a measure of precaution . Coming over the crown of a bit of a rise in [the road]971-the road , [I]0-i clapped down suddenly among the barley and lay waiting . After a while , [a man]519-a man went by that looked to be [a Highlandman]1039-a highlandman , but [I]0-i had never seen [him]519-a man till that hour . Presently after came [Neil of the red head]1040-neil of the red head . The next to go past was [a miller]1041-a miller s cart , and after that nothing but manifest [country people]1042-country people . Here was enough to have turned the most foolhardy from [his]1040-neil of the red head purpose , but [my]0-i inclination ran too strong the other way . [I]0-i argued it out that if [Neil]192-neil was on [that road]1043-that road , it was [the right road to find [him]192-neil in]1044-the right road to find him in , leading direct to [[his]192-neil chief s daughter]1045-his chief s daughter ; as for [the other Highlandman]1046-the other highlandman , if [I]0-i was to be startled off by [every Highlandman [I]0-i saw]1047-every highlandman i saw , [I]0-i would scarce reach anywhere . And having quite satisfied [myself]0-i with this disingenuous debate , [I]0-i made the better speed of it , and came a little after four to [Mrs. Drumond - Ogilvy]268-mrs. drumond - ogilvy s.

Both ladies were within [the house]818-the house ; and upon [my]0-i perceiving [them]1049-them together by the open door , [I]0-i plucked off [my]0-i hat and said , " Here was [a lad]3590-a lad come seeking saxpence , "[0-i] which [I]0-i thought might please [the dowager]1050-the dowager .

[Catriona]189-catriona ran out to greet [me]0-i heartily , and , to [my]0-i surprise , [the old lady]864-the old lady seemed scarce less forward than [herself]864-the old lady . [I]0-i learned long afterwards that [she]864-the old lady had despatched [a horseman]1052-a horseman by daylight to [Rankeillor]176-rankeillor at [the Queensferry]57-the queensferry , whom [she]864-the old lady knew to be the doer for [Shaws]222-davie , and had then in [her]864-the old lady pocket a letter from [that good friend of mine]1053-that good friend of mine , presenting , in the most favourable view , [my]0-i character and prospects . But had [I]0-i read it [I]0-i could scarce have seen more clear in [her]864-the old lady designs . Maybe [I]0-i was countryfeed ; at least , [I]0-i was not so much so as [she]864-the old lady thought ; and it was even to [my]0-i homespun wits , that [she]864-the old lady was bent to hammer up a match between [[her]864-the old lady cousin]1054-her cousin and [a beardless boy that was something of a laird]1055-a beardless boy that was something of a laird in [Lothian]58-lothian .

" [Saxpence]244-saxpence had better take [his]1054-her cousin broth with [us]1056-us , [Catrine]248-catrine , "[864-the old lady] says [she]864-the old lady . " Run and tell [the lasses]3695-the lasses . "[864-the old lady]

And for the little while [we]1056-us were alone was at a good deal of pains to flatter [me]0-i ; always cleverly , always with the appearance of a banter , still calling [me]0-i [Saxpence]244-saxpence , but with such a turn that should rather uplift [me]0-i in [my]0-i own opinion . When [Catriona]189-catriona returned , the design became if possible more obvious ; and [she]189-catriona showed off [the girl]517-the girl s advantages like a horse - couper with a horse . [My]0-i face flamed that [she]189-catriona should think [me]0-i so obtuse . Now [I]0-i would fancy [the girl]517-the girl was being innocently made a show of , and then [I]0-i could have beaten [the old carline wife]1059-the old carline wife with a cudgel ; and now , that perhaps [these two]3138-these two had set [their]3138-these two heads together to entrap [me]0-i , and at that [I]0-i sat and gloomed betwixt [them]3138-these two like the very image of ill - will . At last [the matchmaker]1061-the matchmaker had a better device , which was to leave [the pair of [us]1062-the pair of us]1062-the pair of us alone . When [my]0-i suspicions are anyway roused it is sometimes a little the wrong side of easy to allay [them]1063-them . But though [I]0-i knew what breed [she]189-catriona was of , and that was [a breed of thieves]1064-a breed of thieves , [I]0-i could never look in [Catriona]189-catriona s face and disbelieve [her]189-catriona .

" [I]189-catriona must not ask ? "[189-catriona] says [she]189-catriona , eagerly , the same moment [we]1062-the pair of us were left alone .

" Ah , but to - day [I]0-i can talk with a free conscience , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied . " [I]0-i am lightened of [my]0-i pledge , and indeed after what has come and gone since morning [I]0-i would not have renewed it were it asked . "[0-i]

" Tell [me]189-catriona , "[189-catriona] [she]189-catriona said . " [[My]189-catriona cousin]3098-my cousin will not be so long . "[189-catriona]

So [I]0-i told [her]189-catriona the tale of [the lieutenant]960-the lieutenant from the first step to the last of it , making it as mirthful as [I]0-i could , and , indeed , there was matter of mirth in that absurdity .

" And [I]189-catriona think [you]0-i will be as little fitted for [the rudas men]3697-the rudas men as for [the pretty ladies]3495-the pretty ladies , after all ! "[189-catriona] says [she]189-catriona , when [I]0-i had done . " But what was [[your]0-i father]3247-your father that [he]3247-your father could not learn [you]0-i to draw the sword ! It is most ungentle ; [I]189-catriona have not heard the match of that in [anyone]3224-anyone . "[189-catriona]

" It is most misconvenient at least , "[0-i] said [I]0-i ; " and [I]0-i think [[my]0-i father]417-my father [honest man]3702-honest man ! must have been wool - gathering to learn [me]0-i Latin in the place of it . But [you]0-i see [I]0-i do the best [I]0-i can , and just stand up like [[Lot]269-lot s wife]3703-lot s wife and let [them]3703-lot s wife hammer at [me]0-i . "[0-i]

" Do [you]0-i know what makes [me]1066-i smile ? "[1066-i] said [she]1066-i . " Well , it is this . [I]1066-i am made this way , that [I]1066-i should have been [a man child]3704-a man child . In [my]1066-i own thoughts it is so [I]1066-i am always ; and [I]1066-i go on telling [myself]1066-i about this thing that is to befall and that . Then it comes to the place of the fighting , and it comes over [me]1066-i that [I]1066-i am only [a girl at all events]3705-a girl at all events , and can not hold a sword or give one good blow ; and then [I]1066-i have to twist [my]1066-i story round about , so that the fighting is to stop , and yet [me]1066-i have the best of it , just like [you]0-i and [the lieutenant]960-the lieutenant ; and [I]1066-i am [the boy that makes the fine speeches all through]3707-the boy that makes the fine speeches all through , like [Mr. David Balfour]222-davie . "[1066-i]

" [You]1068-i are [a bloodthirsty maid]3708-a bloodthirsty maid , "[1067-you] said [I.]1067-you

" Well , [I]1068-i know it is good to sew and spin , and to make [samplers]3709-samplers , "[1068-i] [she]1068-i said , " but if [you]1067-you were to do nothing else in [the great world]2967-the great world , [I]1068-i think [you]1067-you will say [yourself]1067-you it is a driech business ; and it is not that [I]1068-i want to kill , [I]1068-i think . Did ever [you]1067-you kill [anyone]3224-anyone ? "[1068-i]

" That [I]1067-you have , as it chances . [Two]3712-two , no less , and [me]1067-you still [a lad that should be at [the college]3714-the college]3713-a lad that should be at the college , "[1067-you] said [I.]1067-you " But yet , in the look - back , [I]1067-you take no shame for it . "[1067-you]

" But how did [you]1067-you feel , then after it ? "[1068-i] [she]1068-i asked .

" [Deed]270-deed , [I]1067-you sat down and grat like [a bairn]3715-a bairn , "[1067-you] said [I.]1067-you

"[0-i]

" Right , "[1068-i] [she]1068-i said , " the right mind of [a man]519-a man ! [I]0-i had a meal with [the two ladies]1076-the two ladies , all very good , served in fine old plate , and the wine excellent , for it seems that [Mrs. Ogilvy]268-mrs. drumond - ogilvy was rich . [Catriona]189-catriona came with [me]0-i as far as to [the garden gate]1079-the garden gate .

" It is long till [I]189-catriona see [you]0-i now ? "[189-catriona] [she]189-catriona asked .

"[189-catriona]

[She]1080-her took up [my]0-i hand and kissed it . This so surprised [my]0-i spirits that [I]0-i cried out like one hurt . The colour came strong in [her]1080-her face , and [she]1080-her looked at [me]0-i and nodded .

" O yes , [Mr. David]222-davie , "[1080-her] said [she]1080-her , " that is what [I]1080-her think of [you]222-davie . The head goes with the lips . "[1080-her]

[I]0-i could read in [her]1080-her face high spirit , and a chivalry like [a brave child]1081-a brave child s ; not anything besides . [She]1080-her kissed [my]0-i hand , as [she]1080-her had kissed [Prince Charlie]170-prince charlie s , with a higher passion than the common kind of clay has any sense of . Nothing before had taught [me]0-i how deep [I]0-i was [[her]1080-her lover]1082-her lover , nor how far [I]0-i had yet to climb to make [her]1080-her think of [me]0-i in such a character . Yet [I]0-i could tell [myself]0-i [I]0-i had advanced some way , and that [her]1080-her heart had beat and [her]1080-her blood flowed at thoughts of [me]0-i .

After that honour [she]1080-her had done [me]0-i [I]0-i could offer no more trivial civility . It was even hard for [me]0-i to speak ; a certain lifting in [her]1080-her voice had knocked directly at the door of [my]0-i own tears .

" [I]0-i praise [God]223-god for [your]1080-her kindness , [dear]3748-dear , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " Farewell , [[my]0-i little friend]3749-my little friend ! "[0-i] giving [her]1080-her that name which [she]1080-her had given to [herself]1080-her ; with which [I]0-i bowed and left [her]1080-her .

[My]0-i way was down [the glen of [the Leith River]62-the leith river]1083-the glen of the leith river , towards [Stockbridge]63-stockbridge and [Silvermills]1-silvermills . [A path]920-a path led in the foot of [it]1085-it , the water bickered and sang in the midst ; the sunbeams overhead struck out of the west among long shadows and as [the valley]1086-the valley turned made like a new scene and a new world of it at every corner . With [Catriona]189-catriona behind and [Alan]185-alan before [me]0-i , [I]0-i was like one lifted up . The place besides , and the hour , and the talking of [the water]3088-the water , infinitely pleased [me]0-i ; and [I]0-i lingered in [my]0-i steps and looked before and behind [me]0-i as [I]0-i went . This was the cause , under [Providence]265-providence , that [I]0-i spied a little in [my]0-i rear a red head among some bushes .

Anger sprang in [my]0-i heart , and [I]0-i turned straight about and walked at a stiff pace to where [I]0-i came from . [The path]1088-the path lay close by the bushes where [I]0-i had remarked the head . The cover came to the wayside , and as [I]0-i passed [I]0-i was all strung up to meet and to resist an onfall . No such thing befell , [I]0-i went by unmeddled with ; and at that fear increased upon [me]0-i . It was still day indeed , but [the place]490-the place exceeding solitary . If [[my]0-i haunters]1090-my haunters had let slip that fair occasion [I]0-i could but judge [they]1090-my haunters aimed at something more than [David Balfour]222-davie . The lives of [Alan]185-alan and [James]181-james weighed upon [my]0-i spirit with the weight of two grown bullocks .

[Catriona]189-catriona was yet in [the garden]1091-the garden walking by [herself]189-catriona .

" [Catriona]189-catriona , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " [you]189-catriona see [me]0-i back again . "[0-i]

"[0-i]

[[No doubt]1092-no doubt]1092-no doubt but [I]0-i spoke bitter and sharp . [My]0-i heart was bitter . [Catriona]189-catriona set [her]189-catriona fingers to [her]189-catriona lips and whistled once , with an exceeding clear , strong , mounting note , as full as a ploughman s.
