"[185-alan] [he]185-alan added with extraordinary bitterness .

" [Alan]185-alan , "[0-i] cried [I]0-i , " [they]3941-they re [all rogues]3945-all rogues and [liars]3946-liars , and [I]0-i m with [ye]185-alan there . The more reason there should be [one decent man in such a land of [thieves]3948-thieves]3947-one decent man in such a land of thieves ! [My]0-i word is passed , and [I]0-i ll stick to it . [I]0-i said long syne to [[your]185-alan kinswoman]3949-your kinswoman that [I]0-i would stumble at no risk . Do [ye]185-alan mind of that ? the night [Red Colin]291-red colin fell , it was . No more [I]0-i will , then . Here [I]0-i stop . [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange promised [me]0-i [my]0-i life : if [he]182-prestongrange s to be mansworn , here [I]0-i ll have to die . "[0-i]

" [Aweel aweel]292-aweel , "[185-alan] said [Alan]185-alan .

All this time [we]1274-we had seen or heard no more of [[our]1274-we pursuers]1275-our pursuers . In truth [we]1274-we had caught [them]1275-our pursuers unawares ; [their]1275-our pursuers whole party as [I]0-i was to learn afterwards had not yet reached the scene ; what there was of [them]1275-our pursuers was spread among [the bents]3942-the bents towards [Gillane]47-gillane . It was quite an affair to call [them]1275-our pursuers in and bring [them]1275-our pursuers over , and [the boat]1266-the boat was making speed . [They]1275-our pursuers were besides but [cowardly fellows]1278-cowardly fellows : [a mere leash of Highland cattle - thieves]1279-a mere leash of highland cattle - thieves , of several clans , [no gentleman]1280-no gentleman there to be [the captain]3428-the captain and the more [they]1275-our pursuers looked at [Alan]185-alan and [me]0-i upon [the beach]1247-the beach , the less [I]0-i must suppose [they]1275-our pursuers liked the look of [us]1283-us .

Whoever had betrayed [Alan]185-alan it was not [the captain]3428-the captain : [he]185-alan was in [the skiff]1285-the skiff [himself]185-alan , steering and stirring up [[his]185-alan oarsmen]1286-his oarsmen , like [a man with [his]185-alan heart in [his]185-alan employ]1287-a man with his heart in his employ . Already [he]185-alan was near in , and the boat securing already [Alan]185-alan s face had flamed crimson with the excitement of [his]185-alan deliverance , when [[our]1283-us friends in the bents]1288-our friends in the bents , either in [their]1288-our friends in the bents despair to see [their]1288-our friends in the bents prey escape [them]1288-our friends in the bents or with some hope of scaring [Andie]213-andie , raised suddenly a shrill cry of several voices .

This sound , arising from what appeared to be [a quite deserted coast]1289-a quite deserted coast , was really very daunting , and [the men in the boat]1290-the men in the boat held water instantly .

" What s this of it ? "[3428-the captain] sings out [the captain]3428-the captain , for [he]3428-the captain was come within an easy hail .

" Freens o mine , "[185-alan] says [Alan]185-alan , and began immediately to wade forth in [the shallow water]1292-the shallow water towards [the boat]1266-the boat . " [Davie]222-davie , "[185-alan] [he]185-alan said , pausing , " [Davie]222-davie , are [ye]222-davie no coming ? [I]185-alan am swier to leave [ye]222-davie . "[185-alan]

" Not a hair of [me]1294-me , "[1294-me] said [I.]1294-me

" [He]185-alan stood part of a second where [he]185-alan was to [his]185-alan knees in the salt water , hesitating .[185-alan]

" [He]185-alan that will to [Cupar]293-cupar , maun to [Cupar]293-cupar , "[185-alan] said [he]185-alan , and swashing in deeper than [his]185-alan waist , was hauled into [the skiff]1285-the skiff , which was immediately directed for [the ship]3120-the ship .

[I]0-i stood where [he]185-alan had left [me]0-i , with [my]0-i hands behind [my]0-i back ; [Alan]185-alan sat with [his]185-alan head turned watching [me]0-i ; and [the boat]1266-the boat drew smoothly away . Of a sudden [I]0-i came the nearest hand to shedding tears , and seemed to [myself]0-i [the most deserted solitary lad in [Scotland]182-prestongrange]1298-the most deserted solitary lad in scotland . With that [I]0-i turned [my]0-i back upon [the sea]1224-the sea and faced [the sandhills]1244-the sandhills . There was no sight or sound of [man]3015-man ; the sun shone on the wet sand and the dry , the wind blew in [the bents]3942-the bents , the gulls made a dreary piping . As [I]0-i passed higher up [the beach]1247-the beach , the sand - lice were hopping nimbly about the stranded tangles . The devil any other sight or sound in [that unchancy place]1304-that unchancy place . And yet [I]0-i knew there were [folk there]3899-folk there , observing [me]0-i , upon some secret purpose . [They]3899-folk there were [no soldiers]1306-no soldiers , or [they]3899-folk there would have fallen on and taken [us]1307-us ere now ; doubtless [they]3899-folk there were [some common rogues]1308-some common rogues hired for [my]0-i undoing , perhaps to kidnap , perhaps to murder [me]0-i outright . From the position of [those engaged]1309-those engaged , [the first]814-the first was the more likely ; from what [I]0-i knew of [their]3899-folk there character and ardency in this business , [I]0-i thought the second very possible ; and the blood ran cold about [my]0-i heart .

[I]0-i had a mad idea to loosen [my]0-i sword in the scabbard ; for though [I]0-i was very unfit to stand up like a gentleman blade to blade , [I]0-i thought [I]0-i could do some scathe in a random combat . But [I]0-i perceived in time the folly of resistance . This was no doubt the joint " expedient "[815-the second] on which [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange and [Fraser]240-mr. simon were agreed . The first , [I]0-i was very sure , had done something to secure [my]0-i life ; [the second]815-the second was pretty likely to have slipped in some contrary hints into the ears of [Neil]192-neil and [[his]192-neil companions]1312-his companions ; and if [I]0-i were to show bare steel [I]0-i might play straight into the hands of [[my]0-i worst enemy]1313-my worst enemy and seal [my]0-i own doom .

These thoughts brought [me]0-i to [the head of [the beach]1247-the beach]1314-the head of the beach . [I]0-i cast a look behind , [the boat]1266-the boat was nearing [the brig]1070-the brig , and [Alan]185-alan flew [his]185-alan handkerchief for a farewell , which [I]0-i replied to with the waving of [my]0-i hand . But [Alan]185-alan [himself]185-alan was shrunk to a small thing in [my]0-i view , alongside of [this pass that lay in front of [me]0-i]1318-this pass that lay in front of me . [I]0-i set [my]0-i hat hard on [my]0-i head , clenched [my]0-i teeth , and went right before [me]0-i up [the face of [the sand - wreath]1320-the sand - wreath]1319-the face of the sand - wreath . It made a hard climb , being steep , and the sand like [water underfoot]1321-water underfoot . But [I]0-i caught hold at last by the long bent - grass on the brae - top , and pulled [myself]0-i to a good footing . The same moment [men]3421-men stirred and stood up here and there , [six or seven of [them]3421-men]1323-six or seven of them , ragged - like knaves , each with a dagger in [his]1324-his hand . The fair truth is , [I]0-i shut [my]0-i eyes and prayed . When [I]0-i opened them again , [the rogues]1325-the rogues were crept the least thing nearer without speech or hurry . Every eye was upon [mine]0-i , which struck [me]0-i with a strange sensation of their brightness , and of the fear with which [they]3421-men continued to approach [me]0-i . [I]0-i held out [my]0-i hands empty ; whereupon [one]503-one asked , with a strong Highland brogue , if [I]0-i surrendered .

" Under protest , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " if [ye]503-one ken what that means , which [I]0-i misdoubt . "[0-i]

At that word , [they]3421-men came all in upon [me]0-i like a flight of birds upon a carrion , seized [me]0-i , took [my]0-i sword , and all the money from [my]0-i pockets , bound [me]0-i hand and foot with some strong line , and cast [me]0-i on a tussock of bent . There [they]3421-men sat about [[their]3421-men captive]1327-their captive in a part of a circle and gazed upon [him]1327-their captive silently like something dangerous , perhaps a lion or a tiger on the spring . Presently this attention was relaxed . [They]3421-men drew nearer together , fell to speech in the Gaelic , and very cynically divided [my]0-i property before [my]0-i eyes . It was [my]0-i diversion in this time that [I]0-i could watch from [my]0-i place the progress of [[my]0-i friend]3036-my friend s escape . [I]0-i saw [the boat]1266-the boat come to [the brig]1070-the brig and be hoisted in , the sails fill , and [the ship]3120-the ship pass out seaward behind [the isles]1332-the isles and by [North Berwick]90-north berwick .

In the course of two hours or so , [more and more ragged Highlandmen]1333-more and more ragged highlandmen kept collecting . [Neil]192-neil among the first , until [the party]515-the party must have numbered near a score . With [each new arrival]1335-each new arrival there was a fresh bout of talk , that sounded like complaints and explanations ; but [I]0-i observed one thing , [none of those who came late]1336-none of those who came late had any share in the division of [my]0-i spoils . The last discussion was very violent and eager , so that once [I]0-i thought [they]1337-they would have quarrelled ; on the heels of which [[their]1337-they company]1338-their company parted , the bulk of [them]1337-they returning westward in a troop , and only three , [Neil]192-neil and [two others]1339-two others , remaining sentries on [the prisoner]498-the prisoner .

" [I]0-i could name one who would be very ill pleased with [your]192-neil day s work , [Neil Duncanson]294-neil , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , when [the rest]1213-the rest had moved away .

[He]192-neil assured [me]0-i in answer [I]0-i should be tenderly used , for [he]192-neil knew [he]192-neil was " acquent wi [the leddy]3950-the leddy . "[192-neil]

This was all [our]1342-we talk , nor did [any other son of man]1343-any other son of man appear upon [that portion of [the coast]1238-the coast]1344-that portion of the coast until the sun had gone down among [the Highland mountains]1346-the highland mountains , and the gloaming was beginning to grow dark . At which hour [I]0-i was aware of [a long , lean , bony - like Lothian man of a very swarthy countenance]1347-a long , lean , bony - like lothian man of a very swarthy countenance , that came towards [us]1342-we among the bents on a farm horse .

" [Lads]3951-lads , "[192-neil] cried [he]192-neil , " has [ye]3951-lads a paper like this ? "[192-neil] and held up one in [his]192-neil hand . [Neil]294-neil produced a second , which [the newcomer]1348-the newcomer studied through a pair of horn spectacles , and saying all was right and [we]1342-we were [the folk [he]192-neil was seeking]1349-the folk he was seeking , immediately dismounted . [I]0-i was then set in [his]192-neil place , [my]0-i feet tied under the horse s belly , and [we]1342-we set forth under the guidance of [the Lowlander]1350-the lowlander . [[His]192-neil path]1351-his path must have been very well chosen , for [we]1342-we met but [one pair a pair of lovers]1352-one pair a pair of lovers the whole way , and these , perhaps taking [us]1342-we to be [free - traders]1353-free - traders , fled on [our]1342-we approach . [We]1342-we were at one time close at [the foot of [Berwick Law]95-berwick law on [the south side]1355-the south side]1354-the foot of berwick law on the south side ; at another , as [we]1342-we passed over [some open hills]1356-some open hills , [I]0-i spied the lights of a clachan and [the old tower of [a church]1358-a church]1357-the old tower of a church among some trees not far off , but too far to cry for help , if [I]0-i had dreamed of it . At last [we]1342-we came again within sound of [the sea]1224-the sea . There was moonlight , though not much ; and by this [I]0-i could see [the three huge towers and broken battlements of [Tantallon]96-tantallon]1360-the three huge towers and broken battlements of tantallon , [that old chief place of [the Red Douglases]1362-the red douglases]1361-that old chief place of the red douglases . The horse was picketed in the bottom of the ditch to graze , and [I]0-i was led within , and forth into [the court]3404-the court , and thence into [the tumble - down stone hall]1364-the tumble - down stone hall . Here [[my]0-i conductors]1365-my conductors built a brisk fire in the midst of [the pavement]1366-the pavement , for there was a chill in the night . [My]0-i hands were loosed , [I]0-i was set by the wall in the inner end , and [the Lowlander]1350-the lowlander having produced provisions [I]0-i was given oatmeal bread and a pitcher of French brandy . This done , [I]0-i was left once more alone with [[my]0-i three Highlandmen]1368-my three highlandmen . [They]1368-my three highlandmen sat close by the fire drinking and talking ; the wind blew in by the breaches , cast about the smoke and flames , and sang in the tops of [the towers]1369-the towers ; [I]0-i could hear [the sea]1224-the sea under [the cliffs]1371-the cliffs , and , [my]0-i mind being reassured as to [my]0-i life , and [my]0-i body and spirits wearied with the day s employment , [I]0-i turned upon one side and slumbered .

[I]0-i had no means of guessing at what hour [I]0-i was wakened , only the moon was down and the fire was low . [My]0-i feet were now loosed , and [I]0-i was carried through [the ruins]1372-the ruins and down [the cliff - side]1373-the cliff - side by a precipitous path to where [I]0-i found [[a fisher]1374-a fisher s boat]1375-a fisher s boat in [a haven of the rocks]1376-a haven of the rocks . This [I]0-i was had on board of , and [we]1377-we began to put forth from [the shore]1220-the shore in a fine starlight .

CHAPTER XIV THE BASS

[I]0-i had no thought where [they]1379-they were taking [me]0-i ; only looked here and there for the appearance of [a ship]563-a ship ; and there ran the while in [my]0-i head a word of [Ransome]295-ransome s the twenty - pounders . If [I]0-i were to be exposed a second time to that same former danger of [the plantations]1381-the plantations , [I]0-i judged it must turn ill with [me]0-i ; there was no second [Alan]185-alan ; and no second shipwreck and [spare yard]1382-spare yard to be expected now ; and [I]0-i saw [myself]0-i hoe tobacco under the whip s lash . The thought chilled [me]0-i ; the air was sharp upon the water , the stretchers of [the boat]1266-the boat drenched with a cold dew : and [I]0-i shivered in [my]0-i place beside [the steersman]1384-the steersman . This was [the dark man whom [I]0-i have called hitherto [the Lowlander]1350-the lowlander]1385-the dark man whom i have called hitherto the lowlander ; [his]1385-the dark man whom i have called hitherto the lowlander name was [Dale]296-tam , ordinarily called [Black Andie]297-andie . Feeling the thrill of [my]0-i shiver , [he]1384-the steersman very kindly handed [me]0-i a rough jacket full of fish - scales , with which [I]0-i was glad to cover [myself]0-i .

" [I]0-i thank [you]1384-the steersman for this kindness , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " and will make so free as to repay it with a warning . [You]1384-the steersman take a high responsibility in this affair . [You]1384-the steersman are not like [these ignorant , barbarous Highlanders]3952-these ignorant , barbarous highlanders , but know what the law is and the risks of [those that break it]3953-those that break it . "[0-i]

" [I]1384-the steersman am no just exactly what [ye]0-i would ca [an extremist for the law]3954-an extremist for the law , "[1384-the steersman] says [he]1384-the steersman , " at the best of times ; but in this business [I]1384-the steersman act with a good warranty . "[1384-the steersman]

" What are [you]1384-the steersman going to do with [me]0-i ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" Nae harm , "[1384-the steersman] said [he]1384-the steersman , " nae harm ava . [Ye]0-i ll have [strong freens]3955-strong freens , [I]1384-the steersman m thinking . [Ye]0-i ll be richt eneuch yet . "[1384-the steersman]

There began to fall a greyness on the face of [the sea]1224-the sea ; little dabs of pink and red , like coals of slow fire , came in the east ; and at the same time the geese awakened , and began crying about [the top of [the Bass]97-the bass]1388-the top of the bass . It is just [the one crag of rock]1389-the one crag of rock , as [everybody]587-everybody knows , but great enough to carve [a city]500-a city from . [The sea]1224-the sea was extremely little , but there went a hollow plowter round [the base of [it]1224-the sea]1393-the base of it . With the growing of the dawn [I]0-i could see [it]1224-the sea clearer and clearer ; the straight crags painted with sea - birds droppings like a morning frost , the sloping top of it green with grass , the clan of white geese that cried about the sides , and [the black , broken buildings of [the prison]1395-the prison sitting close on [the sea s edge]1396-the sea s edge]1394-the black , broken buildings of the prison sitting close on the sea s edge .

At the sight the truth came in upon [me]0-i in a clap .

" It s there [you]1397-you re taking [me]0-i ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried .

" Just to [the Bass]97-the bass , [mannie]3956-mannie , "[1397-you] said [he]1397-you : " Whaur [the auld saints]3957-the auld saints were afore [ye]3956-mannie , and [I]1397-you misdoubt if [ye]3956-mannie have come so fairly by [your]3956-mannie preeson . "[1397-you]

" But none dwells there now , "[0-i] [I]0-i cried ; " [the place]490-the place is long a ruin . "[0-i]

" It ll be the mair pleisand a change for the solan geese , then , "[1397-you] quoth [Andie]297-andie dryly .

The day coming slowly brighter [I]0-i observed on the bilge , among the big stones with which [fisherfolk]1398-fisherfolk ballast [[their]1398-fisherfolk boats]1399-their boats , several kegs and baskets , and a provision of fuel . All these were discharged upon the crag . [Andie]297-andie , [myself]0-i , and [my]0-i three Highlanders [I]0-i call [them]1400-them mine , although it was the other way about , landed along with [them]1400-them . The sun was not yet up when [the boat]1266-the boat moved away again , the noise of the oars on the thole - pins echoing from [the cliffs]1371-the cliffs , and left [us]1403-us in [our]1403-us singular reclusion :

[Andie Dale]298-andie was the Prefect as [I]0-i would jocularly call [him]298-andie of [the Bass]97-the bass , being at once [the shepherd]1404-the shepherd and [the gamekeeper of [that small and rich estate]1406-that small and rich estate]1405-the gamekeeper of that small and rich estate . [He]298-andie had to mind the dozen or so of sheep that fed and fattened on the grass of [the sloping part of [it]97-the bass]1407-the sloping part of it , like beasts grazing the roof of [a cathedral]1408-a cathedral . [He]298-andie had charge besides of the solan geese that roosted in [the crags]1409-the crags ; and from these an extraordinary income is derived . [The young]1410-the young are dainty eating , as much as two shillings a - piece being a common price , and paid willingly by epicures ; even the grown birds are valuable for their oil and feathers ; and a part of [the minister]1411-the minister s stipend of [North Berwick]98-north berwick is paid to this day in solan geese , which makes it in [some folks eyes [a parish]1413-a parish]1412-some folks eyes a parish to be coveted . To perform these several businesses , as well as to protect the geese from [poachers]1414-poachers , [Andie]298-andie had frequent occasion to sleep and pass days together on [the crag]1415-the crag ; and [we]1416-we found [the man at [home]658-home]1417-the man at home there like [a farmer in [his]1419-a farmer in his steading steading]1419-a farmer in his steading . Bidding [us]1416-we all shoulder some of the packages , a matter in which [I]0-i made haste to bear a hand , [he]298-andie led [us]1416-we in by a locked gate , which was the only admission to [the island]1420-the island , and through [the ruins of [the fortress]1422-the fortress]1421-the ruins of the fortress , to [[the governor]1423-the governor s house]1424-the governor s house . There [we]1416-we saw by the ashes in the chimney and a standing bed - place in one corner , that [he]298-andie made [his]298-andie usual occupation .

This bed [he]298-andie now offered [me]0-i to use , saying [he]298-andie supposed [I]0-i would set up to be [gentry]1425-gentry .

" [[My]0-i gentrice]3959-my gentrice has nothing to do with where [I]0-i lie , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " [I]0-i bless God [I]0-i have lain hard ere now , and can do the same again with thankfulness . While [I]0-i am [here]3174-here , [Mr. Andie]299-andie , if that be [your]299-andie name , [I]0-i will do [my]0-i part and take [my]0-i place beside [the rest of [you]299-andie]3961-the rest of you ; and [I]0-i ask [you]299-andie on the other hand to spare [me]0-i [your]299-andie mockery , which [I]0-i own [I]0-i like ill . "[0-i]

[He]1426-he grumbled a little at this speech , but seemed upon reflection to approve it . Indeed , [he]1426-he was [a long - headed , sensible man]1427-a long - headed , sensible man , and [a good Whig and Presbyterian]1428-a good whig and presbyterian ; read daily in a pocket Bible , and was both able and eager to converse seriously on religion , leaning more than a little towards the Cameronian extremes . [His]1426-he morals were of a more doubtful colour . [I]0-i found [he]1426-he was deep in the free trade , and used [the ruins of [Tantallon]96-tantallon]1429-the ruins of tantallon for a magazine of smuggled merchandise . As for [a gauger]1430-a gauger , [I]0-i do not believe [he]1426-he valued the life of one at half - a - farthing . But [that part of [the coast of [Lothian]58-lothian]1432-the coast of lothian]1431-that part of the coast of lothian is to this day as [wild a place]1433-wild a place , and [the commons there]1434-the commons there as rough [a crew]1435-a crew , as any in [Scotland]182-prestongrange .

One incident of [my]0-i imprisonment is made memorable by a consequence it had long after . There was [a warship]1436-a warship at this time stationed in [the Firth]99-the firth , [the Seahorse]100-the seahorse , [Captain Palliser]300-captain palliser . [It]1437-it chanced [she]1436-a warship was cruising in the month of September , plying between [Fife]101-fife and [Lothian]58-lothian , and sounding for sunk dangers . Early one fine morning [she]1436-a warship was seen about two miles to east of [us]1438-us , where [she]1436-a warship lowered [a boat]1439-a boat , and seemed to examine [the Wildfire Rocks]1440-the wildfire rocks and [Satan s Bush]102-satan s bush , famous dangers of [that coast]1441-that coast . And presently after having got [[her]1436-a warship boat]1442-her boat again , [she]1436-a warship came before the wind and was headed directly for [the Bass]97-the bass . This was very troublesome to [Andie]299-andie and [the Highlanders]301-highlanders ; the whole business of [my]0-i sequestration was designed for privacy , and here , with [a navy captain]1443-a navy captain perhaps blundering ashore , it looked to become public enough , if it were nothing worse . [I]0-i was in a minority of one , [I]0-i am [no Alan to fall upon so many]1444-no alan to fall upon so many , and [I]0-i was far from sure that [a warship]1436-a warship was the least likely to improve [my]0-i condition . All which considered , [I]0-i gave [Andie]299-andie [my]0-i parole of good behaviour and obedience , and was had briskly to [the summit of [the rock]1447-the rock]1446-the summit of the rock , where [we]1448-we all lay down , at [the cliff s edge]1449-the cliff s edge , in different places of observation and concealment . [The Seahorse]1450-the seahorse came straight on till [I]0-i thought [she]1450-the seahorse would have struck , and [we]1448-we looking giddily down could see [the ship s company at [[their]1451-the ship s company at their quarters quarters]1452-their quarters]1451-the ship s company at their quarters and hear [the leadsman]1453-the leadsman singing at the lead . Then [she]1450-the seahorse suddenly wore and let fly a volley of [I]0-i know not how many great guns . [The rock]1447-the rock was shaken with the thunder of the sound , the smoke flowed over [our]1448-we heads , and the geese rose in number beyond computation or belief . To hear [their]1451-the ship s company at their quarters screaming and to see the twinkling of [their]1451-the ship s company at their quarters wings , made a most inimitable curiosity ; and [I]0-i suppose it was after this somewhat childish pleasure that [Captain Palliser]300-captain palliser had come so near [the Bass]97-the bass . [He]300-captain palliser was to pay dear for it in time . During [his]300-captain palliser approach [I]0-i had the opportunity to make a remark upon the rigging of [that ship]1455-that ship by which [I]0-i ever after knew it miles away ; and this was a means under Providence of [my]0-i averting from [a friend]461-a friend a great calamity , and inflicting on [Captain Palliser]300-captain palliser [himself]300-captain palliser a sensible disappointment .

All the time of [my]0-i stay on [the rock]1447-the rock [we]1448-we lived well . [We]1448-we had small ale and brandy , and oatmeal , of which [we]1448-we made [our]1448-we porridge night and morning . At times [a boat]1439-a boat came from [the Castleton]103-the castleton and brought [us]1448-we a quarter of mutton , for the sheep upon [the rock]1447-the rock [we]1448-we must not touch , these being specially fed to market . The geese were unfortunately out of season , and [we]1448-we let [them]1460-them be . [We]1448-we fished [ourselves]1448-we , and yet more often made the geese to fish for [us]1448-we : observing one when [he]1461-he had made a capture and scaring [him]1461-he from [his]1461-he prey ere [he]1461-he had swallowed it .

The strange nature of [this place]1462-this place , and the curiosities with which it abounded , held [me]0-i busy and amused . Escape being impossible , [I]0-i was allowed [my]0-i entire liberty , and continually explored [the surface of [the isle]1464-the isle]1463-the surface of the isle wherever it might support [the foot of [man]3015-man]1465-the foot of man . [The old garden of [the prison]1395-the prison]1467-the old garden of the prison was still to be observed , with flowers and pot - herbs running wild , and some ripe cherries on a bush . A little lower stood [a chapel]1469-a chapel or [[a hermit]1470-a hermit s cell]1471-a hermit s cell ; who built or dwelt in [it]1395-the prison , none may know , and the thought of [its]1395-the prison age made a ground of many meditations . [The prison]1395-the prison , too , where [I]0-i now bivouacked with [Highland cattle - thieves]1473-highland cattle - thieves , was a place full of history , both human and divine . [I]0-i thought it strange [so many saints]1474-so many saints and [martyrs]1475-martyrs should have gone by [there]636-there so recently , and left not so much as a leaf out of [their]1474-so many saints Bibles , or a name carved upon the wall , while [the rough soldier lads that mounted guard upon the battlements]1477-the rough soldier lads that mounted guard upon the battlements had filled [the neighbourhood]1478-the neighbourhood with [their]1477-the rough soldier lads that mounted guard upon the battlements mementoes broken tobacco - pipes for the most part , and that in a surprising plenty , but also metal buttons from [their]1477-the rough soldier lads that mounted guard upon the battlements coats . There were times when [I]0-i thought [I]0-i could have heard the pious sound of psalms out of [the martyr s dungeons]1479-the martyr s dungeons , and seen [the soldiers]711-the soldiers tramp [the ramparts]1481-the ramparts with [their]711-the soldiers glinting pipes , and the dawn rising behind [them]711-the soldiers out of [the North Sea]104-the north sea .

No doubt it was a good deal [Andie]299-andie and [his]299-andie tales that put these fancies in [my]0-i head . [He]299-andie was extraordinarily well acquainted with the story of [the rock]1447-the rock in all particulars , down to the names of [private soldiers]1483-private soldiers , [[his]299-andie father]418-his father having served [there]636-there in that same capacity . [He]299-andie was gifted besides with a natural genius for narration , so that [the people]1486-the people seemed to speak and the things to be done before [your]1487-your face . This gift of [his]299-andie and [my]0-i assiduity to listen brought [us]1488-us the more close together . [I]0-i could not honestly deny but what [I]0-i liked [him]299-andie ; [I]0-i soon saw that [he]299-andie liked [me]0-i ; and indeed , from the first [I]0-i had set [myself]0-i out to capture [his]299-andie good - will . An odd circumstance to be told presently effected this beyond [my]0-i expectation ; but even in early days [we]1488-us made a friendly pair to be [a prisoner]528-a prisoner and [[his]528-a prisoner gaoler]1490-his gaoler .

[I]0-i should trifle with [my]0-i conscience if [I]0-i pretended [my]0-i stay upon [the Bass]97-the bass was wholly disagreeable . It seemed to [me]0-i [a safe place , as though [I]0-i was escaped [there]636-there out of [my]0-i troubles]1491-a safe place , as though i was escaped there out of my troubles . No harm was to be offered [me]0-i ; a material impossibility , rock and [the deep sea]1493-the deep sea , prevented [me]0-i from fresh attempts ; [I]0-i felt [I]0-i had [my]0-i life safe and [my]0-i honour safe , and there were times when [I]0-i allowed [myself]0-i to gloat on [them]1494-them like stolen waters . At other times [my]0-i thoughts were very different , [I]0-i recalled how strong [I]0-i had expressed [myself]0-i both to [Rankeillor]176-rankeillor and to [Stewart]185-alan ; [I]0-i reflected that [my]0-i captivity upon [the Bass]97-the bass , in view of a great part of [the coasts of [Fife]101-fife and [Lothian]58-lothian]1495-the coasts of fife and lothian , was a thing [I]0-i should be thought more likely to have invented than endured ; and in the eyes of [these two gentlemen]1496-these two gentlemen , at least , [I]0-i must pass for [a boaster]1497-a boaster and [a coward]1498-a coward . Now [I]0-i would take this lightly enough ; tell [myself]0-i that so long as [I]0-i stood well with [Catriona Drummond]189-catriona , the opinion of [the rest of man]1499-the rest of man was but moonshine and spilled water ; and thence pass off into those meditations of a lover which are so delightful to [himself]1500-himself and must always appear so surprisingly idle to [a reader]1501-a reader . But anon the fear would take [me]0-i otherwise ; [I]0-i would be shaken with a perfect panic of self - esteem , and these supposed hard judgments appear an injustice impossible to be supported . With that another train of thought would [he]1500-himself presented , and [I]0-i had scarce begun to be concerned about [men]3421-men s judgments of [myself]0-i , than [I]0-i was haunted with the remembrance of [James Stewart]181-james in [[his]181-james dungeon]1503-his dungeon and the lamentations of [[his]181-james wife]2962-his wife . Then , indeed , passion began to work in [me]0-i ; [I]0-i could not forgive [myself]0-i to sit there idle : it seemed if [I]0-i were [a man]519-a man at all that [I]0-i could fly or swim out of [my]0-i place of safety ; and it was in such humours and to amuse [my]0-i self - reproaches that [I]0-i would set the more particularly to win the good side of [Andie Dale]298-andie .

At last , when [we]1506-we two were alone on [the summit of the rock]1446-the summit of the rock on a bright morning , [I]0-i put in some hint about a bribe . [He]181-james looked at [me]0-i , cast back [his]181-james head , and laughed out loud .

" Ay , [you]181-james re funny , [Mr. Dale]302-mr. dale , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " but perhaps if [you]181-james ll glance an eye upon that paper [you]181-james may change [your]181-james note . "[0-i]

The stupid [Highlanders]301-highlanders had taken from [me]0-i at the time of [my]0-i seizure nothing but hard money , and the paper [I]0-i now showed [Andie]298-andie was an acknowledgment from [the British Linen Company]423-the british linen company for a considerable sum .

[He]181-james read it . " [Troth]266-troth , and [ye]266-troth re nane sae ill aff , "[181-james] said [he]181-james .

" [I]0-i thought that would maybe vary [your]181-james opinions , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" Hout ! "[181-james] said [he]181-james . " It shows [me]181-james [ye]266-troth can bribe ; but [I]181-james m no to be bribit . "[181-james]

" [We]3962-we ll see about that yet a while , "[0-i] says [I.]0-i " And first , [I]0-i ll show [you]181-james that [I]0-i know what [I]0-i am talking . [You]181-james have orders to detain [me]0-i here till after Thursday , 21st September . "[0-i]

" [Ye]266-troth re no a thegether wrong either , "[298-andie] says [Andie]298-andie . " [I]298-andie m to let [you]181-james gang , bar orders contrair , on Saturday , the 23rd . "[298-andie]

[I]0-i could not but feel there was something extremely insidious in this arrangement . That [I]0-i was to re - appear precisely in time to be too late would cast the more discredit on [my]0-i tale , if [I]0-i were minded to tell one ; and this screwed [me]0-i to fighting point .

" Now then , [Andie]298-andie , [you]298-andie that kens [the world]3073-the world , listen to [me]0-i , and think while [ye]298-andie listen , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " [I]0-i know there are [great folks in the business]3964-great folks in the business , and [I]0-i make no doubt [you]298-andie have [their]3964-great folks in the business names to go upon . [I]0-i have seen some of [them]3964-great folks in the business [myself]0-i since this affair began , and said [my]0-i say into [their]3964-great folks in the business faces too . But what kind of a crime would this be that [I]0-i had committed ? or what kind of a process is this that [I]0-i am fallen under ? To be apprehended by [some ragged John - Hielandman]303-some ragged john - hielandman on August 30th , carried to a rickle of old stones that is now neither [fort nor gaol]3965-fort nor gaol whatever [it]3966-it once was but just [the gamekeeper s lodge of the Bass Rock]3967-the gamekeeper s lodge of the bass rock , and set free again , September 23rd , as secretly as [I]0-i was first arrested does that sound like law to [you]298-andie ? or does it sound like justice ? or does it not sound honestly like a piece of some low dirty intrigue , of which [the very folk that meddle with it]3968-the very folk that meddle with it are ashamed ? "[0-i]

" [I]298-andie canna gainsay [ye]298-andie , [Shaws]222-davie . It looks unco underhand , "[298-andie] says [Andie]298-andie . " And werenae [the folk guid sound Whigs]3969-the folk guid sound whigs and true - blue Presbyterians [I]298-andie would has seen [them]3969-the folk guid sound whigs ayont [Jordan]304-jordan and [Jeroozlem]105-jeroozlem or [I]298-andie would have set hand to it .
