" [The Master of [Lovat]243-lovat]3970-the master of lovat ll be [a braw Whig]3971-a braw whig , "[0-i] says [I]0-i , " and [a grand Presbyterian]3972-a grand presbyterian . "[0-i]

" [I]298-andie ken naething by [him]3970-the master of lovat , "[298-andie] said [he]298-andie . " [I]298-andie hae nae trokings wi [Lovats]305-lovats . "[298-andie]

" No , it ll be [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange that [you]298-andie ll be dealing with , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" Ah , but [I]298-andie ll no tell [ye]298-andie that , "[298-andie] said [Andie]298-andie .

" Little need when [I]0-i ken , "[0-i] was [my]0-i retort .

" There s just the ae thing [ye]298-andie can be fairly sure of , [Shaws]222-davie , "[298-andie] says [Andie]298-andie . " And that is that try as [ye]298-andie please [I]298-andie m no dealing wi [yoursel]298-andie ; nor yet [I]298-andie amnae goin to , "[298-andie] [he]298-andie added .

" Well , [Andie]298-andie , [I]0-i see [I]0-i ll have to be speak out plain with [you]298-andie , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied . And told [him]298-andie so much as [I]0-i thought needful of the facts .

[He]298-andie heard [me]0-i out with some serious interest , and when [I]0-i had done , seemed to consider a little with [himself]298-andie .

" [Shaws]222-davie , "[298-andie] said [he]298-andie at last , " [I]298-andie ll deal with the naked hand . It s a queer tale , and no very creditable , the way [you]298-andie tell it ; and [I]298-andie m far frae minting that is other than the way that [ye]298-andie believe it . As for [yoursel]298-andie , [ye]298-andie seem to [me]298-andie rather [a dacent - like young man]3973-a dacent - like young man . But [me]298-andie , that s aulder and mair judeecious , see perhaps a wee bit further forrit in the job than what [ye]298-andie can dae . And here the maitter clear and plain to [ye]298-andie . There ll be nae skaith to [yoursel]298-andie if [I]298-andie keep [ye]298-andie here ; far free that , [I]298-andie think [ye]298-andie ll be a hantle better by it . There ll be nae skaith to the kintry just ae mair Hielantman hangit Gude kens , a guid riddance ! On the ither hand , it would be considerable skaith to [me]298-andie if [I]298-andie would let [you]298-andie free . [Sae]3974-sae , speakin as [a guid Whig]3975-a guid whig , an honest freen to [you]298-andie , and an anxious freen to [[my]298-andie ainsel]3976-my ainsel , the plain fact is that [I]298-andie think [ye]298-andie ll just have to bide [here]3174-here [wi]3978-wi [Andie]298-andie an [the solans]3979-the solans . "[298-andie]

" [Andie]298-andie , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , laying [my]0-i hand upon [his]1509-his knee , " [this Hielantman]3980-this hielantman s innocent . "[0-i]

" Ay , it s a peety about that , "[1509-his] said [he]1509-his . " But [ye]298-andie see , in this warld , the way [God]223-god made it , [we]3981-we cannae just get a thing that [we]3981-we want . "[1509-his]

CHAPTER XV [BLACK ANDIE]297-andie S TALE OF [TOD LAPRAIK]306-tod lapraik

[I]0-i have yet said little of [the Highlanders]1510-the highlanders . [They]1510-the highlanders were [all three of [the followers of [James More]181-james]1512-the followers of james more , which bound the accusation very tight about [[their]1510-the highlanders master]1513-their master s neck]1511-all three of the followers of james more , which bound the accusation very tight about their master s neck . [All]938-all understood a word or two of English , but [Neil]294-neil was [the only one who judged [he]294-neil had enough of it for general converse , in which when once [he]294-neil got embarked [[his]294-neil company]1516-his company]1515-the only one who judged he had enough of it for general converse , in which when once he got embarked his company was often tempted to the contrary opinion . [They]1510-the highlanders were tractable , simple creatures ; showed much more courtesy than might have been expected from [their]1510-the highlanders raggedness and [their]1510-the highlanders uncouth appearance , and fell spontaneously to be like [three servants for [Andie]297-andie and [myself]0-i]1517-three servants for andie and myself .

Dwelling in [that isolated place]1518-that isolated place , in [the old falling ruins of [a prison]1520-a prison]1519-the old falling ruins of a prison , and among endless strange sounds of [the sea]1224-the sea and the sea - birds , [I]0-i thought [I]0-i perceived in [them]1510-the highlanders early the effects of superstitious fear . When there was nothing doing [they]1510-the highlanders would either lie and sleep , for which [their]1510-the highlanders appetite appeared insatiable , or [Neil]294-neil would entertain [the others]511-the others with stories which seemed always of a terrifying strain . If neither of these delights were within reach if perhaps [two]3712-two were sleeping and [the third]1524-the third could find no means to follow [their]1510-the highlanders example [I]0-i would see [him]294-neil sit and listen and look about [him]294-neil in a progression of uneasiness , starting , [his]294-neil face blenching , [his]294-neil hands clutched , [a man strung like a bow]1525-a man strung like a bow . The nature of these fears [I]0-i had never an occasion to find out , but the sight of them was catching , and the nature of the place that [we]1526-our were in favourable to alarms . [I]0-i can find no word for it in [the English]106-the english , but [Andie]297-andie had an expression for it in the Scots from which [he]297-andie never varied .

" Ay , "[294-neil] [he]294-neil would say , " it s an unco place , the Bass . "[294-neil]

It is so [I]0-i always think of it . It was [an unco place]1527-an unco place by night , unco by day ; and these were unco sounds , of the calling of [the solans]3979-the solans , and the plash of [the sea]1224-the sea and the rock echoes , that hung continually in [our]1526-our ears . It was chiefly so in moderate weather . When the waves were anyway great they roared about [the rock]1447-the rock like thunder and the drums of armies , dreadful but merry to hear ; and it was in the calm days that [a man]519-a man could daunt [himself]519-a man with listening not [a Highlandman]1039-a highlandman only , as [I]0-i several times experimented on [myself]0-i , so many still , hollow noises haunted and reverberated in [the porches of [the rock]1447-the rock]1533-the porches of the rock .

This brings [me]0-i to a story [I]0-i heard , and a scene [I]0-i took part in , which quite changed [our]1526-our terms of living , and had a great effect on [my]0-i departure . It chanced one night [I]0-i fell in a muse beside the fire and that little air of [Alan]185-alan s coming back to [my]0-i memory began to whistle . A hand was laid upon [my]0-i arm , and the voice of [Neil]294-neil bade [me]0-i to stop , for it was not " canny musics . "[294-neil]

" Not canny ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked . " How can that be ? "[294-neil]

" [Na]279-na , "[294-neil] said [he]294-neil ; " it will be made by [a bogle]3982-a bogle and [her]3982-a bogle wanting ta heid upon [his]294-neil body . "[294-neil] 13

" Well , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " there can be no bogles here , [Neil]294-neil ; for it s not likely [they]3982-a bogle would fash [themselves]3982-a bogle to frighten geese . "[0-i]

" Ay ? "[297-andie] says [Andie]297-andie , " is that what [ye]297-andie think of it ! But [I]297-andie ll can tell [ye]297-andie there s been waur nor bogles here . "[297-andie]

" What s waur than bogles , [Andie]297-andie ? "[0-i] said [I.]0-i

" [Warlocks]3983-warlocks , "[294-neil] said [he]294-neil . " Or [a warlock]3984-a warlock at the least of it . And that s a queer tale , too , "[294-neil] [he]294-neil added . " And if [ye]297-andie would like , [I]294-neil ll tell it [ye]297-andie . "[294-neil]

To be sure [we]1535-we were [all of the one mind]1536-all of the one mind , and even [the Highlander that had the least English of the three]1537-the highlander that had the least english of the three set [himself]1537-the highlander that had the least english of the three to listen with all [his]1537-the highlander that had the least english of the three might .

The Tale of [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik

[[My]0-i faither]1538-my faither , [Tam Dale]296-tam , peace to [[his]296-tam banes]1539-his banes , was [a wild , sploring lad]1540-a wild , sploring lad in [his]296-tam young days , [wi]1541-wi little wisdom and little grace . [He]296-tam was fond of [a lass and fond of a glass , and fond of a ran - dan]1542-a lass and fond of a glass , and fond of a ran - dan ; but [I]0-i could never hear tell that [he]296-tam was muckle use for honest employment . Frae ae thing to [anither]1543-anither , [he]296-tam listed at last for [a sodger]1544-a sodger and was in [the garrison of [this fort]1546-this fort]1545-the garrison of this fort , which was [the first way that ony of [the Dales]107-the dales]1547-the first way that ony of the dales cam to set foot upon [the Bass]97-the bass . Sorrow upon that service ! [The governor]1423-the governor brewed [his]1423-the governor ain ale ; it seems it was the warst conceivable . [The rock]1447-the rock was proveesioned free [the shore]1220-the shore with [vivers]1551-vivers , the thing was ill - guided , and there were whiles when [they]1552-they but to fish and shoot [solans]1553-solans for [their]1552-they diet . To crown a , thir was the Days of [the Persecution]307-the persecution . The perishin cauld chalmers were all occupeed wi sants and [martyrs]1475-martyrs , the saut of the yearth , of which it wasnae worthy . And though [Tam Dale]296-tam carried a firelock there , [a single sodger]1555-a single sodger , and liked [a lass]1556-a lass and a glass , as [I]0-i was sayin , the mind of [the man]3029-the man was mair just than set with [his]3029-the man position . [He]296-tam had glints of the glory of the kirk ; there were whiles when [his]296-tam dander rase to see [the Lord]1558-the lord s sants misguided , and shame covered [him]296-tam that [he]296-tam should be haulding [a can le]1559-a can le or carrying a firelock in so black a business . There were nights of it when [he]296-tam was here on sentry , [the place]490-the place a wheesht , the frosts o winter maybe riving in the wa s , and [he]296-tam would hear ane o [the prisoners]1561-the prisoners strike up a psalm , and [the rest]1213-the rest join in , and the blessed sounds rising from the different chalmers or [dungeons]1563-dungeons , [I]0-i would raither say so that [this auld craig in [the sea]1224-the sea]1564-this auld craig in the sea was like a pairt of Heev n. Black shame was on [his]296-tam saul ; [his]296-tam sins hove up before [him]296-tam muckle as [the Bass]175-the bass , and above a , that chief sin , that [he]296-tam should have a hand in hagging and hashing at [Christ s Kirk]1566-christ s kirk . But the truth is that [he]296-tam resisted the spirit . Day cam , there were [the rousing compainions]1567-the rousing compainions , and [his]296-tam guid resolves depairtit .

In thir days , dwalled upon the Bass [a man of [God]223-god]1568-a man of god , [Peden]308-peden [the Prophet]1569-the prophet was [his]308-peden name . [Ye]1570-ye ll have heard tell of [Prophet Peden]308-peden . There was never the wale of [him]308-peden sinsyne , and it s a question wi mony if there ever was [his]308-peden like afore . [He]308-peden was wild s a peat - hag , fearsome to look at , fearsome to hear , [his]308-peden face like the day of judgment . The voice of [him]308-peden was like a solan s and dinnle d in folks lugs , and the words of [him]308-peden like coals of fire .

Now there was [a lass on the rock]1571-a lass on the rock , and [I]0-i think [she]1571-a lass on the rock had little to do , for it was [nae place far decent weemen]1572-nae place far decent weemen ; but it seems [she]1571-a lass on the rock was bonny , and [her]1571-a lass on the rock and [Tam Dale]296-tam were very well agreed . It befell that [Peden]308-peden was in [the gairden]1573-the gairden [[his]308-peden lane]3880-his lane at the praying when [Tam]296-tam and [the lass]3448-the lass cam by ; and what should [the lassie]1576-the lassie do but mock with laughter at the sant s devotions ? [He]308-peden rose and lookit at the twa o [them]1577-them , and [Tam]296-tam s knees knoitered thegether at the look of [him]308-peden . But whan [he]308-peden spak , it was mair in sorrow than in anger . " [Poor thing]3985-poor thing , poor thing ! "[308-peden] says [he]308-peden , and it was [the lass]3448-the lass [he]308-peden lookit at , " [I]308-peden hear [you]3448-the lass skirl and laugh , "[308-peden] [he]308-peden says , " but [the Lord]3830-the lord has a deid shot prepared for [you]3448-the lass , and at that surprising judgment [ye]3448-the lass shall skirl but the ae time ! "[308-peden] Shortly thereafter [she]3448-the lass was daundering on the craigs wi twa - three sodgers , and it was a blawy day . There cam a gowst of wind , claught [her]3448-the lass by the coats , and awa wi [her]3448-the lass bag and baggage . And it was remarked by [the sodgers]1579-the sodgers that [she]3448-the lass gied but the ae skirl .

[Nae]1580-nae doubt this judgment had some weicht upon [Tam Dale]296-tam ; but it passed again and [him]308-peden none the better . Ae day [he]308-peden was flyting [wi]1581-wi [anither sodger - lad]1582-anither sodger - lad . " Deil hae [me]308-peden ! "[308-peden] quo [Tam]296-tam , for [he]308-peden was [a profane swearer]1583-a profane swearer . And there was [Peden]308-peden glowering at [him]308-peden , [gash]1584-gash an waefu ; [Peden]308-peden wi [his]308-peden lang chafts an luntin een , [the maud]1585-the maud happed about [his]308-peden kist , and the hand of [him]308-peden held out wi the black nails upon the finger - nebs for [he]308-peden had [nae]1580-nae care of the body . " Fy , fy , [poor man]3987-poor man ! "[308-peden] cries [he]308-peden , " [the poor fool man]3988-the poor fool man ! Deil hae [me]308-peden , quo [he]308-peden ; an [I]308-peden see the deil at [his]308-peden oxter . "[308-peden] The conviction of guilt and grace cam in on [Tam]215-tam like [the deep sea]1493-the deep sea ; [he]308-peden flang doun the pike that was in [his]308-peden hands " [I]308-peden will nae mair lift arms against the cause o [Christ]309-christ ! "[308-peden] says [he]308-peden , and was as gude s word . There was a sair fyke in the beginning , but [the governor]1423-the governor , seeing [him]308-peden resolved , gied [him]308-peden [his]308-peden discharge , and [he]308-peden went and dwallt and merried in North [Berwick]90-north berwick , and had aye a gude name with [honest folk]1588-honest folk free that day on .

It was in the year [seeventeen hunner]310-seeventeen hunner and [sax]1589-sax that the Bass cam in the hands o [the Da rymples]1590-the da rymples , and there was [twa men soucht the chairge of it]1591-twa men soucht the chairge of it . [Baith]233-balfour of baith were weel qualified , for [they]233-balfour of baith had baith been [sodgers]1592-sodgers in [the garrison]1593-the garrison , and kent the gate to handle solans , and the seasons and values of [them]233-balfour of baith . [Forby]311-forby that [they]233-balfour of baith were baith or [they]233-balfour of baith baith seemed [earnest professors]1594-earnest professors and [men of comely conversation]1595-men of comely conversation . The first of [them]233-balfour of baith was just [Tam Dale]296-tam , [[my]0-i faither]1538-my faither . [The second]815-the second was ane Lapraik , whom [the folk]1598-the folk ca d [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik maistly , but whether for [his]306-tod lapraik name or [his]306-tod lapraik nature [I]0-i could never hear tell . [Weel]242-weel , [Tam]296-tam gaed to see [Lapraik]306-tod lapraik upon this business , and took [me]0-i , that was [a toddlin laddie]1599-a toddlin laddie , by the hand . [Tod]306-tod lapraik had [his]306-tod lapraik dwallin in [the lang loan benorth the kirkyaird]1600-the lang loan benorth the kirkyaird . It s [a dark uncanny loan]1601-a dark uncanny loan , forby that the kirk has aye had an ill name since the days o [James the Saxt]312-james the saxt and [the deevil]1602-the deevil s cantrips played therein when [the Queen]1603-the queen was on [the seas]1604-the seas ; and as for [[Tod]306-tod lapraik s house]1605-tod s house , [it]1605-tod s house was in [the mirkest end]1606-the mirkest end , and was little liked by [some that kenned the best]1607-some that kenned the best . The door was on [the sneck]1608-the sneck that day , and [me]0-i and [[my]0-i faither]1538-my faither gaed straucht in . [Tod]306-tod lapraik was a wabster to [his]306-tod lapraik trade ; [his]306-tod lapraik loom stood in the but . There [he]306-tod lapraik sat , a muckle fat , white hash of [a man like [creish]1611-creish]1610-a man like creish , wi a kind of a holy smile that gart [me]0-i scunner . The hand of [him]306-tod lapraik aye cawed [the shuttle]1612-the shuttle , but [his]306-tod lapraik een was steeked . [We]1613-we cried to [him]306-tod lapraik by [his]306-tod lapraik name , [we]1613-we skirled in the deid lug of [him]306-tod lapraik , [we]1613-we shook [him]306-tod lapraik by the shou ther . Nae mainner o service ! There [he]306-tod lapraik sat on [his]306-tod lapraik dowp , an cawed [the shuttle]1612-the shuttle and smiled like creish .

" [God]223-god be guid to [us]1613-we , "[296-tam] says [Tam Dale]296-tam , " this is [no canny]3989-no canny ? "[296-tam]

[He]296-tam had [jimp]1615-jimp said the word , when [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik cam to [himsel]296-tam .

" Is this [you]296-tam , [Tam]296-tam ? "[296-tam] says [he]296-tam . " [Haith]313-haith , [man]3015-man ! [I]306-tod lapraik m blythe to see [ye]3015-man . [I]306-tod lapraik whiles fa into a bit dwam like this , "[306-tod lapraik] [he]306-tod lapraik says ; " its frae the stamach . "[306-tod lapraik]

[Weel]242-weel , [they]1616-they began to crack about the Bass and which of [them twa]1617-them twa was to get the warding o t , and [little by little cam]1618-little by little cam to very ill words , and twined in anger . [I]0-i mind weel that as [[my]0-i faither]1538-my faither and [me]0-i gaed hame again , [he]306-tod lapraik [cam ower]314-cam ower and ower the same expression , how little [he]306-tod lapraik likit [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik and [his]306-tod lapraik dwams .

" Dwam ! "[306-tod lapraik] says [he]306-tod lapraik . " [I]306-tod lapraik think [folk]441-folk [hae]3992-hae brunt for dwams like yon . "[306-tod lapraik]

[Aweel]292-aweel , [[my]0-i faither]1538-my faither got the Bass and [Tod]306-tod lapraik had to go wantin . It was remembered sinsyne what way [he]306-tod lapraik had ta en the thing . " [Tam]296-tam , "[306-tod lapraik] says [he]306-tod lapraik , " [ye]296-tam hae gotten the better o [me]306-tod lapraik aince mair , and [I]306-tod lapraik hope , "[306-tod lapraik] says [he]306-tod lapraik , " [ye]296-tam ll find at least a that [ye]296-tam expeckit at [the Bass]97-the bass . "[306-tod lapraik] Which have since been thought remarkable expressions . At last the time came for [Tam Dale]296-tam to take [young solans]1621-young solans . This was a business [he]296-tam was weel used wi , [he]296-tam had been [a craigsman frae]1622-a craigsman frae [a laddie]1623-a laddie , and trustit nane but [himsel]296-tam . So there was [he]296-tam hingin by a line an speldering on the craig face , whaur its hieest and steighest . [Fower tenty lads]1624-fower tenty lads were on the tap , hauldin the line and mindin for [his]296-tam signals . But whaur [Tam]296-tam hung there was naething but the craig , and [the sea belaw]1625-the sea belaw , and [the solans]3979-the solans skirlin and flying . It was a braw spring morn , and [Tam]296-tam whustled as [he]296-tam claught in the young geese . Mony s the time [I]0-i ve heard [him]296-tam tell of this experience , and aye the swat ran upon [the man]3029-the man .

It chanced , [ye]1628-ye see , that [Tam]296-tam keeked up , and [he]296-tam was awaur of a muckle solan , and the solan pyking at the line . [He]296-tam thocht this by - ordinar and outside the creature s habits . [He]296-tam minded that ropes was unco saft things , and [the solan]1629-the solan s neb and the Bass Rock unco hard , and that twa hunner feet were raither mair than [he]296-tam would care to fa .

" Shoo ! "[296-tam] says [Tam]296-tam . " Awa , [bird]3993-bird ! Shoo , awa wi [ye]3993-bird ! "[296-tam] says [he]296-tam .

[The solan keekit]1630-the solan keekit doon into [Tam]296-tam s face , and there was something unco in [the creature]1631-the creature s ee . Just the ae keek it gied , and back to the rope . But now it wroucht and warstl t like a thing dementit . There never was [the solan]1629-the solan made that wroucht as that solan wroucht ; and it seemed to understand [its]1631-the creature employ brawly , birzing the saft rope between the neb of it and a crunkled jag o stane .

There gaed a cauld stend o fear into [Tam]296-tam s heart . " This thing is nae bird , "[296-tam] thinks [he]296-tam . [His]296-tam een turnt backward in [his]296-tam heid and the day gaed black aboot [him]296-tam . " If [I]296-tam get a dwam here , "[296-tam] [he]296-tam toucht , " it s by wi [Tam Dale]296-tam . "[296-tam] And [he]296-tam signalled for [the lads]3175-the lads to pu [him]296-tam up .

And it seemed [the solan]1629-the solan understood about signals . For nae sooner was the signal made than [he]296-tam let be the rope , spried [his]296-tam wings , squawked out loud , took a turn flying , and dashed straucht at [Tam Dale]296-tam s een . [Tam]296-tam had a knife , [he]296-tam gart the cauld steel glitter . And it seemed [the solan]1629-the solan understood about knives , for nae suner did the steel glint in the sun than [he]296-tam gied the ae squawk , but laighter , like a body disappointit , and flegged aff about the roundness of the craig , and [Tam]296-tam saw [him]296-tam nae mair . And as sune as that thing was gane , [Tam]296-tam s heid drapt upon [his]296-tam shouther , and [they]3175-the lads pu d [him]296-tam up like a deid corp , dadding on the craig .

A dram of brandy which [he]296-tam went never without broucht [him]296-tam to [his]296-tam mind , or what was left of it . Up [he]296-tam sat .

" Rin , [Geordie]208-king george , rin to [the boat]1266-the boat , mak sure of [the boat]1266-the boat , [man rin]3996-man rin ! "[296-tam] [he]296-tam cries , " or yon solan ll have it awa , "[296-tam] says [he]296-tam .

[The fower lads]1636-the fower lads stared at ither , an tried to whilly - wha [him]296-tam to be quiet . But naething would satisfy [Tam Dale]296-tam , till ane o [them]1636-the fower lads had startit on [aheid]1637-aheid to stand sentry on [the boat]1266-the boat . The ithers askit if [he]296-tam was for down again .

" Na , "[296-tam] says [he]296-tam , " and niether [you]1636-the fower lads nor [me]296-tam , "[296-tam] says [he]296-tam , " and as sune as [I]296-tam can win to stand on [my]296-tam twa feet [we]1636-the fower lads ll be aff frae [this craig o [Sawtan]110-sawtan]3997-this craig o sawtan . "[296-tam]

Sure eneuch , nae time was lost , and that was ower muckle ; for before [they]1636-the fower lads won to [North Berwick]1639-north berwick [Tam]296-tam was in a crying fever . [He]296-tam lay a the simmer ; and [wha]1640-wha was sae kind as come speiring for [him]296-tam , but [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik ! Folk thocht afterwards that ilka time [Tod]306-tod lapraik cam near [the house]818-the house the fever had worsened . [I]0-i kenna for that ; but what [I]0-i ken the best , that was the end of it .

It was about this time o the year ; [[my]0-i grandfaither]1642-my grandfaither was out at the white fishing ; and like a bairn , [I]0-i but to gang wi [him]1642-my grandfaither . [We]1643-we had a grand take , [I]0-i mind , and the way that the fish lay broucht [us]1643-we near in by [the Bass]97-the bass , whaur [we]1643-we foregaithered wi anither boat that belanged to [a man Sandie Fletcher in [Castleton]103-the castleton]1644-a man sandie fletcher in castleton . [He]1644-a man sandie fletcher in castleton s no lang deid neither , or [ye]1645-ye could speir at [himsel]1644-a man sandie fletcher in castleton . Weel , [Sandie]315-sandie hailed .

" What s yon on [the Bass]97-the bass ? "[1644-a man sandie fletcher in castleton] says [he]1644-a man sandie fletcher in castleton .

" On [the Bass]97-the bass ? "[315-sandie] says grandfaither .

" Ay , "[315-sandie] says [Sandie]315-sandie , " on the green side o t. "[315-sandie]

" Whatten kind of a thing ? "[315-sandie] says grandfaither . " There cannae be naething on [the Bass]97-the bass but just the sheep . "[315-sandie]

" It looks unco like a body , "[315-sandie] quo [Sandie]315-sandie , who was nearer in .

" A body ! "[1643-we] says [we]1643-we , and [we]1643-we none of [us]1643-we likit that . For there was [nae boat]1646-nae boat that could have brought [a man]519-a man , and the key o [the prison]1395-the prison yett hung ower [my]0-i faither s at hame in the press bed .

[We]1643-we keept the twa boats close for company , and crap in nearer hand . [Grandfaither]316-grandfaither had a gless , for [he]316-grandfaither had been [a sailor]1649-a sailor , and [the captain of a smack]1650-the captain of a smack , and had lost [her]1651-her on [the sands of [Tay]112-tay]1652-the sands of tay . And when [we]1643-we took the glass to it , sure eneuch there was [a man]519-a man . [He]519-a man was in a crunkle o green brae , a wee below the chaipel , a by [[his]519-a man lee lane]1654-his lee lane , and lowped and flang and danced like a daft quean at a waddin .

" It s [Tod]306-tod lapraik , "[1655-grandfather] says [grandfather]1655-grandfather , and passed the gless to [Sandie]315-sandie .

" Ay , it s [him]519-a man , "[315-sandie] says [Sandie]315-sandie .

" Or ane in the likeness o [him]519-a man , "[315-sandie] says grandfaither .

" Sma is [the differ]3998-the differ , "[315-sandie] quo [Sandie]315-sandie . " De il or [warlock]3999-warlock , [I]315-sandie ll try the gun at [him]315-sandie , "[315-sandie] quo [he]315-sandie , and broucht up a fowling - piece that [he]315-sandie aye carried , for [Sandie]315-sandie was a notable famous shot in all [that country]1656-that country .

" Haud [your]315-sandie hand , [Sandie]315-sandie , "[315-sandie] says grandfaither ; " [we]4000-we maun see [clearer]317-clearer first , "[315-sandie] says [he]315-sandie , " or this may be a dear day s wark to the baith of [us]4000-we . "[315-sandie]

" Hout ! "[315-sandie] says [Sandie]315-sandie , " this is [the Lord]3830-the lord s judgment surely , and be damned to it , "[315-sandie] says [he]315-sandie .

" Maybe ay , and maybe no , "[1658-worthy man] says [[my]0-i grandfaither]1642-my grandfaither , [worthy man]1658-worthy man ! " But have [you]315-sandie a mind of [the Procurator Fiscal]4002-the procurator fiscal , that [I]315-sandie think [ye]315-sandie ll have foregaithered wi before , "[315-sandie] says [he]315-sandie .

This was ower true , and [Sandie]315-sandie was a wee thing set ajee . " [Aweel]292-aweel , [Edie]318-edie , "[315-sandie] says [he]315-sandie , " and what would be [your]315-sandie way of it ? "[315-sandie]

" Ou , just this , "[316-grandfaither] says [grandfaither]316-grandfaither . " Let [me]316-grandfaither that has [the fastest boat gang]4003-the fastest boat gang back to [North Berwick]98-north berwick , and let [you]315-sandie bide [here]3174-here and keep an eye on [Thon]4005-thon . If [I]316-grandfaither cannae find [Lapraik]306-tod lapraik , [I]316-grandfaither ll join [ye]315-sandie and [the twa of [us]1659-us]4006-the twa of us ll have a crack wi [him]306-tod lapraik . But if [Lapraik]306-tod lapraik s at hame , [I]316-grandfaither ll rin up the flag at [the harbour]4007-the harbour , and [ye]315-sandie can try Thon Thing wi the gun . "[316-grandfaither]

[Aweel]292-aweel , so it was agreed between [them]1659-us twa . [I]0-i was just a bairn , an clum in [[Sandie]315-sandie s boat]1660-sandie s boat , whaur [I]0-i thoucht [I]0-i would see the best of the employ . [[My]0-i grandsire]1661-my grandsire gied [Sandie]315-sandie a siller tester to pit in [his]315-sandie gun wi the leid draps , bein mair deidly again bogles . And then [the as boat]1662-the as boat set aff for [North Berwick]98-north berwick , an the tither lay whaur it was and watched the wanchancy thing on the brae - side .

A the time [we]1663-we lay there it lowped and flang and capered and span like a teetotum , and whiles [we]1663-we could hear it skelloch as it span . [I]0-i hae seen [lassies]1664-lassies , [the daft queans]1665-the daft queans , that would lowp and dance a winter s nicht , and still be lowping and dancing when the winter s day cam in . But there would be fowk there to hauld [them]1664-lassies company , and [the lads]3175-the lads to egg [them]1664-lassies on ; and this thing was its lee - lane . And there would be a fiddler diddling [his]1667-his elbock in the chimney - side ; and this thing had nae music but the skirling of [the solans]3979-the solans . And [the lassies]1669-the lassies were bits o young things wi the reid life dinnling and stending in [[their]1669-the lassies members]1670-their members ; and this was [a muckle , fat , creishy man]1671-a muckle , fat , creishy man , and [him]1671-a muckle , fat , creishy man fa n in the vale o years . Say what [ye]1672-ye like , [I]0-i maun say what [I]0-i believe . It was joy was in the creature s heart , the joy o hell , [I]0-i daursay : joy whatever . Mony a time [I]0-i have askit [mysel]0-i why [witches]1673-witches and [warlocks]3983-warlocks should sell [their]1664-lassies sauls whilk are [their]1664-lassies maist dear possessions and be auld , duddy , wrunkl t [wives]1675-wives or auld , [feckless , doddered men]1676-feckless , doddered men ; and then [I]0-i mind upon [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik dancing a the hours by [[his]306-tod lapraik lane]3880-his lane in the black glory of [his]306-tod lapraik heart . [Nae]1678-nae doubt [they]1679-they burn for it muckle in hell , but [they]1679-they have a grand time here of it , whatever ! and [the Lord]3830-the lord forgie [us]1681-we !

[Weel]242-weel , at the hinder end , [we]1681-we saw the wee flag yirk up to the mast - heid upon [the harbour rocks]1682-the harbour rocks . That was a [Sandie]315-sandie waited for . [He]315-sandie up wi the gun , took a deleeberate aim , an pu d the trigger . There cam a bang and then ae waefu skirl frae the Bass . And there were [we]1681-we rubbin [our]1681-we een and lookin at ither like [daft folk]1683-daft folk . For wi the bang and the skirl the thing had clean disappeared . The sun glintit , the wund blew , and there was the bare yaird whaur the Wonder had been lowping and flinging but ae second syne .

The hale way hame [I]0-i roared and grat wi the terror o that dispensation . [The grawn folk]1684-the grawn folk were nane sae muckle better ; there was little said in [[Sandie]315-sandie s boat]1660-sandie s boat but just the name of [God]223-god ; and when [we]1681-we won in by [the pier]1686-the pier , [the harbour rocks]1682-the harbour rocks were fair black wi [the folk]1598-the folk waitin [us]1681-we . It seems [they]1598-the folk had fund [Lapraik]306-tod lapraik in ane of [his]306-tod lapraik dwams , cawing [the shuttle]1612-the shuttle and smiling . Ae lad [they]1598-the folk sent to hoist the flag , and the rest abode there in [the wabster s house]1690-the wabster s house . [You]1691-you may be sure [they]1598-the folk liked it little ; but it was a means of grace to severals that stood there praying in to [themsel]1598-the folk s for nane cared to pray out loud and looking on thon awesome thing as it cawed [the shuttle]1612-the shuttle . [Syne]113-syne , upon a suddenty , and [wi]1693-wi [the ae dreidfu skelloch]1694-the ae dreidfu skelloch , [Tod]306-tod lapraik sprang up frae [his]306-tod lapraik hinderlands and fell forrit on [the wab]1695-the wab , a bluidy corp .

When [the corp]1696-the corp was examined [the leid draps]319-the leid draps hadnae played buff upon [the warlock]1697-the warlock s body ; sorrow [a leid drap]1698-a leid drap was to be fund ! but there was grandfaither s siller tester in the puddock s heart of [him]306-tod lapraik .

[Andie]297-andie had scarce done when there befell a mighty silly affair that had its consequence . [Neil]294-neil , as [I]0-i have said , was [himself]294-neil [a great narrator]1699-a great narrator . [I]0-i have heard since that [he]294-neil knew all the stories in [the Highlands]29-the highlands ; and thought much of [himself]294-neil , and was thought much of by [others]1700-others on the strength of it . [Now Andie]297-andie s tale reminded [him]294-neil of one [he]294-neil had already heard .

" [She]4008-she would ken that story afore , "[294-neil] [he]294-neil said . " [She]4008-she was the story of [Uistean More M Gillie Phadrig]320-uistean more m gillie phadrig and [the Gavar Vore]321-the gavar vore . "[294-neil]

" It is no sic a thing , "[297-andie] cried [Andie]297-andie . " It is the story of [[my]294-neil faither]1538-my faither now wi [God]223-god and [Tod Lapraik]306-tod lapraik . And the same in [your]297-andie beard , "[294-neil] says [he]294-neil ; " and keep the tongue of [ye]297-andie inside [your]297-andie Hielant chafts ! "[294-neil]

In dealing with [Highlanders]301-highlanders it will be found , and has been shown in history , how well it goes with [Lowland gentlefolk]1701-lowland gentlefolk ; but the thing appears scarce feasible for Lowland commons . [I]0-i had already remarked that [Andie]297-andie was continually on the point of quarrelling with [[our]1702-our three MacGregors]1703-our three macgregors , and now , sure enough , it was to come .

" Thir will be no words to use to [shentlemans]4010-shentlemans , "[294-neil] says [Neil]294-neil .

" [Shentlemans]322-shentlemans ! "[297-andie] cries [Andie]297-andie . " [Shentlemans]322-shentlemans , [ye]322-shentlemans hielant stot ! If [God]223-god would give [ye]322-shentlemans the grace to see [yoursel]322-shentlemans the way that ithers see [ye]322-shentlemans , [ye]322-shentlemans would throw [[your]322-shentlemans denner]4011-your denner up . "[297-andie]

There came some kind of a Gaelic oath from [Neil]294-neil , and the black knife was in [his]294-neil hand that moment .

There was no time to think ; and [I]0-i caught [the Highlander]1704-the highlander by the leg , and had [him]1704-the highlander down , and [his]1704-the highlander armed hand pinned out , before [I]0-i knew what [I]0-i was doing . [[His]294-neil comrades]1705-his comrades sprang to rescue [him]294-neil , [Andie]297-andie and [I]0-i were without weapons , [the Gregara]194-the gregara three to two . It seemed [we]1706-we were beyond salvation , when [Neil]294-neil screamed in [his]294-neil own tongue , ordering [the others]511-the others back , and made [his]294-neil submission to [myself]0-i in a manner the most abject , even giving [me]0-i up [his]294-neil knife which upon a repetition of [his]294-neil promises [I]0-i returned to [him]294-neil on the morrow .

Two things [I]0-i saw plain : the first , that [I]0-i must not build too high on [Andie]297-andie , who had [shrunk against the wall and stood there , as pale as death , till the affair was over]1708-shrunk against the wall and stood there , as pale as death , till the affair was over ; the second , the strength of [my]0-i own position with [the Highlanders]1510-the highlanders , who must have received extraordinary charges to be tender of [my]0-i safety . But if [I]0-i thought [Andie]297-andie came not very well out in courage , [I]0-i had no fault to find with [him]297-andie upon the account of gratitude . It was not so much that [he]297-andie troubled [me]0-i with thanks , as that [his]297-andie whole mind and manner appeared changed ; and as [he]297-andie preserved ever after a great timidity of [[our]1710-our companions]1711-our companions , [he]297-andie and [I]0-i were yet more constantly together .

CHAPTER XVI THE MISSING WITNESS

On the seventeenth , the day [I]0-i was trysted with [the Writer]547-the writer , [I]0-i had much rebellion against fate . The thought of [him]297-andie waiting in [the King]590-the king s Arms , and of what [he]297-andie would think , and what [he]297-andie would say when next [we]1710-our met , tormented and oppressed [me]0-i . The truth was unbelievable , so much [I]0-i had to grant , and it seemed cruel hard [I]0-i should be posted as [a liar]1714-a liar and [a coward]1498-a coward , and have never consciously omitted what it was possible that [I]0-i should do . [I]0-i repeated this form of words with a kind of bitter relish , and re - examined in that light the steps of [my]0-i behaviour . It seemed [I]0-i had behaved to [James Stewart]181-james as [a brother]720-a brother might ; all the past was a picture that [I]0-i could be proud of , and there was only the present to consider . [I]0-i could not swim [the sea]1224-the sea , nor yet fly in the air , but there was always [Andie]297-andie . [I]0-i had done [him]297-andie a service , [he]297-andie liked [me]0-i ; [I]0-i had a lever there to work on ; if it were just for decency , [I]0-i must try once more with [Andie]297-andie .

It was late afternoon ; there was no sound in all [the Bass]97-the bass but the lap and bubble of [a very quiet sea]1718-a very quiet sea ; and [[my]0-i four companions]1719-my four companions were all crept apart , [the three Macgregors]190-the glengyle macgregors higher on [the rock]1447-the rock , and [Andie]297-andie with [his]297-andie Bible to [a sunny place among [the ruins]1372-the ruins]1721-a sunny place among the ruins ; there [I]0-i found [him]297-andie in deep sleep , and , as soon as [he]297-andie was awake , appealed to [him]297-andie with some fervour of manner and a good show of argument .

" If [I]297-andie thoucht it was to do guid to [ye]0-i , [Shaws]222-davie ! "[297-andie] said [he]297-andie , staring at [me]0-i over [his]297-andie spectacles .

" It s to save another , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " and to redeem [my]0-i word . What would be more good than that ? Do [ye]297-andie no mind the scripture , [Andie]297-andie ? And [you]297-andie with the Book upon [your]297-andie lap ! What shall it profit [a man]519-a man if [he]519-a man gain [the whole world]3512-the whole world ? "[0-i]

" Ay , "[297-andie] said [he]297-andie , " that s grand for [you]0-i . But where do [I]297-andie come in ! [I]297-andie have [my]297-andie word to redeem the same s yoursel . And what are [ye]0-i asking [me]297-andie to do , but just to sell it [ye]0-i for siller ? "[297-andie]

" [Andie]297-andie ! have [I]0-i named the name of siller ? "[0-i] cried [I.]0-i

" Ou , the name s naething "[297-andie] , said [he]297-andie ; " the thing is there , whatever . It just comes to this ; if [I]297-andie am to service [ye]0-i the way that [you]0-i propose , [I]297-andie ll lose [my]297-andie lifelihood . Then it s clear [ye]0-i ll have to make it up to [me]297-andie , and a pickle mair , for [your]0-i ain credit like . And what s that but just a bribe ? And if even [I]297-andie was certain of the bribe ! But by a that [I]297-andie can learn , it s far frae that ; and if [you]0-i were to hang , where would [I]297-andie be ? [Na]279-na : the thing s no possible . And just awa wi [ye]0-i like [a bonny lad]4014-a bonny lad ! and let [Andie]297-andie read [his]297-andie chapter . "[297-andie]

[I]0-i remember [I]0-i was at bottom a good deal gratified with this result ; and the next humour [I]0-i fell into was one [I]0-i had near said of gratitude to [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange , who had saved [me]0-i , in this violent , illegal manner , out of the midst of [my]0-i dangers , temptations , and perplexities . But this was both too flimsy and too cowardly to last [me]0-i long , and the remembrance of [James]181-james began to succeed to the possession of [my]0-i spirits . The 21st , the day set for the trial , [I]0-i passed in such misery of mind as [I]0-i can scarce recall to have endured , save perhaps upon [Isle Earraid]323-isle earraid only . Much of the time [I]0-i lay on a brae - side betwixt sleep and waking , [my]0-i body motionless , [my]0-i mind full of violent thoughts . Sometimes [I]0-i slept indeed ; but [the court - house of [Inverary]39-inverary]1723-the court - house of inverary and [the prisoner]498-the prisoner glancing on all sides to find [[his]498-the prisoner missing witness]1725-his missing witness , followed [me]0-i in slumber ; and [I]0-i would wake again with a start to darkness of spirit and distress of body . [I]0-i thought [Andie]297-andie seemed to observe [me]0-i , but [I]0-i paid [him]297-andie little heed . Verily , [my]0-i bread was bitter to [me]0-i , and [my]0-i days a burthen .

Early the next morning Friday , 22nd [a boat]1439-a boat came with provisions , and [Andie]297-andie placed a packet in [my]0-i hand . The cover was without address but sealed with a Government seal . It enclosed two notes . " [Mr. Balfour]222-davie can now see for [himself]222-davie it is too late to meddle . [His]222-davie conduct will be observed and [his]222-davie discretion rewarded . "[297-andie] So ran the first , which seemed to be laboriously writ with the left hand . There was certainly nothing in these expressions to compromise [the writer]547-the writer , even if [that person]1728-that person could be found ; the seal , which formidably served instead of signature , was affixed to a separate sheet on which there was no scratch of writing ; and [I]0-i had to confess that so far [[my]0-i adversaries]803-my adversaries knew what [they]803-my adversaries were doing , and to digest as well as [I]0-i was able the threat that peeped under the promise .

But the second enclosure was by far the more surprising . It was in [a lady]505-a lady s hand of writ . " [Maister Dauvit Balfour]236-dauvit balfour is informed [a friend]461-a friend was speiring for [him]222-davie and [her]189-catriona eyes were of the grey , "[505-a lady] it ran and seemed so extraordinary a piece to come to [my]0-i hands at such a moment and under cover of a Government seal , that [I]0-i stood stupid . [Catriona]189-catriona s grey eyes shone in [my]0-i remembrance . [I]0-i thought , with a bound of pleasure , [she]189-catriona must be [the friend]1731-the friend . But who should [the writer]547-the writer be , to have [her]189-catriona billet thus enclosed with [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange s ? And of all wonders , why was it thought needful to give [me]0-i this pleasing but most inconsequent intelligence upon [the Bass]1733-the bass ? For [the writer]547-the writer , [I]0-i could hit upon none possible except [Miss Grant]234-miss grant . [[Her]189-catriona family]1735-her family , [I]0-i remembered , had remarked on [Catriona]189-catriona s eyes and even named [her]189-catriona for [their]1735-her family colour ; and [she]189-catriona [herself]189-catriona had been much in the habit to address [me]0-i with a broad pronunciation , by way of a sniff , [I]0-i supposed , at [my]0-i rusticity . No doubt , besides , but [she]189-catriona lived in [the same house]761-the same house as this letter came from . So there remained but one step to be accounted for ; and that was how [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange should have permitted [her]189-catriona at all in an affair so secret , or let [her]189-catriona daft - like billet go in the same cover with [his]182-prestongrange own . But even here [I]0-i had a glimmering . For , first of all , there was something rather alarming about [the young lady]3012-the young lady , and [papa]3356-papa might be more under [her]189-catriona domination than [I]0-i knew . And , second , there was [the man]3029-the man s continual policy to be remembered , how [his]3029-the man conduct had been continually mingled with caresses , and [he]3029-the man had scarce ever , in the midst of so much contention , laid aside a mask of friendship . [He]3029-the man must conceive that [my]0-i imprisonment had incensed [me]0-i . Perhaps this little jesting , friendly message was intended to disarm [my]0-i rancour ?

[I]0-i will be honest and [I]0-i think it did . [I]0-i felt a sudden warmth towards that beautiful [Miss Grant]234-miss grant , that [she]234-miss grant should stoop to so much interest in [my]0-i affairs . The summoning up of [Catriona]189-catriona moved [me]0-i of itself to milder and more cowardly counsels . If [the Advocate]2990-the advocate knew of [her]3012-the young lady and [our]1741-our acquaintance if [I]0-i should please [him]2990-the advocate by some of that " discretion "[2990-the advocate] at which [his]2990-the advocate letter pointed to what might not this lead ! In vain is the net prepared in the sight of any fowl , [the Scripture]324-the scripture says . Well , fowls must be wiser than [folk]441-folk ! For [I]0-i thought [I]0-i perceived the policy , and yet fell in with it .

[I]0-i was in this frame , [my]0-i heart beating , the grey eyes plain before [me]0-i like two stars , when [Andie]297-andie broke in upon [my]0-i musing .

" [I]297-andie see [ye]0-i has gotten guid news , "[297-andie] said [he]297-andie .

[I]0-i found [him]297-andie looking curiously in [my]0-i face ; with that there came before [me]0-i like a vision of [James Stewart]181-james and [the court of [Inverary]39-inverary]1743-the court of inverary ; and [my]0-i mind turned at once like a door upon its hinges . [Trials]325-trials , [I]0-i reflected , sometimes draw out longer than is looked for . Even if [I]0-i came to [Inverary]39-inverary just too late , something might yet be attempted in the interests of [James]181-james and in those of [my]0-i own character , the best would be accomplished . In a moment , it seemed without thought , [I]0-i had a plan devised .

" [Andie]297-andie , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " is it still to be to - morrow ? "[0-i]

[He]297-andie told [me]0-i nothing was changed .

" Was anything said about the hour ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

[He]297-andie told [me]0-i it was to be two o clock afternoon .

" And about the place ? "[0-i] [I]0-i pursued .

" Whatten place ? "[297-andie] says [Andie]297-andie .

" [The place [I]297-andie am to be landed at]4016-the place i am to be landed at ? "[297-andie] said I.

[He]297-andie owned there was nothing as to that .

" Very well , then , "[0-i] [I]0-i said , " this shall be [mine]0-i to arrange . The wind is in the east , [[my]0-i road]4017-my road lies westward : keep [[your]297-andie boat]4018-your boat , [I]0-i hire it ; let [us]4019-us work up the Forth all day ; and land [me]0-i at two o clock to - morrow at the westmost [we]4019-us ll can have reached . "[0-i]

" [Ye]0-i daft callant ! "[297-andie] [he]297-andie cried ; " [ye]0-i would try for [Inverary]39-inverary after a ! "[297-andie]

" Just that , [Andie]297-andie , "[0-i] says [I.]0-i

" Weel , [ye]0-i re ill to beat ! "[297-andie] says [he]297-andie . " And [I]297-andie was a kind o sorry for [ye]0-i a day yesterday , "[297-andie] [he]297-andie added . " [Ye]0-i see , [I]297-andie was never entirely sure till then , which way of it [ye]0-i really wantit . "[297-andie]

Here was a spur to a lame horse !

" A word in [your]297-andie ear , [Andie]297-andie , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " This plan of [mine]0-i has another advantage yet . [We]4019-us can leave [these Hielandman]4020-these hielandman behind [us]4019-us on [the rock]1447-the rock , and one of [[your]297-andie boats]4022-your boats from [the Castleton]103-the castleton can bring [them]4020-these hielandman off to - morrow . [Yon Neil]326-yon neil has a queer eye when [he]326-yon neil regards [you]297-andie ; maybe , if [I]0-i was once out of the gate there might be knives again ; these red - shanks are unco grudgeful . And if there should come to be any question , here is [your]297-andie excuse . [Our]4019-us lives were in danger by [these savages]4023-these savages ; being answerable for [my]0-i safety , [you]297-andie chose the part to bring [me]0-i from [[their]4023-these savages neighbourhood]4024-their neighbourhood and detain [me]0-i the rest of the time on board [[your]297-andie boat]4018-your boat : and do [you]297-andie know , [Andie]297-andie ? "[0-i] says [I]0-i , with a smile , " [I]0-i think it was very wisely chosen . "[0-i]

" The truth is [I]297-andie have nae goo for [Neil]326-yon neil , "[297-andie] says [Andie]297-andie , " nor [he]326-yon neil for [me]297-andie , [I]297-andie m thinking ; and [I]297-andie would like ill to come to [my]297-andie hands wi [the man]3029-the man . [Tam Anster]327-tam anster will make a better hand of it with the cattle onyway . "[297-andie] For [this man]1744-this man , [Anster]327-tam anster , came from [Fife]101-fife , where the Gaelic is still spoken . " Ay , ay ! "[297-andie] says [Andie]297-andie , " [Tam]327-tam anster ll can deal with [them]4027-them the best . And troth ! the mair [I]297-andie think of it , the less [I]297-andie see [we]4028-we would be required . [The place]490-the place ay , feggs ! [they]4027-them had forgot [the place]490-the place . Eh , [Shaws]222-davie , [ye]222-davie re a lang - heided chield when [ye]222-davie like ! Forby that [I]297-andie m awing [ye]222-davie [my]297-andie life , "[297-andie] [he]297-andie added , with more solemnity , and offered [me]0-i [his]297-andie hand upon the bargain .

Whereupon , with scarce more words , [we]1745-we stepped suddenly on board [the boat]1266-the boat , cast off , and set the lug . [The Gregara]194-the gregara were then busy upon breakfast , for the cookery was [their]194-the gregara usual part ; but , one of [them]194-the gregara stepping to the battlements , [our]1745-we flight was observed before [we]1745-we were twenty fathoms from [the rock]1447-the rock ; and the three of [them]194-the gregara ran about [the ruins]1372-the ruins and the landing - shelf , for all [the world]3073-the world like ants about a broken nest , hailing and crying on [us]1745-we to return . [We]1745-we were still in both the lee and the shadow of the rock , which last lay broad upon [the waters]1750-the waters , but presently came forth in almost the same moment into the wind and sunshine ; the sail filled , [the boat]1266-the boat heeled to the gunwale , and [we]1745-we swept immediately beyond sound of [the men]3722-the men s voices . To what terrors [they]194-the gregara endured upon [the rock]1447-the rock , where [they]194-the gregara were now deserted without the countenance of [any civilised person]1754-any civilised person or so much as the protection of a Bible , no limit can be set ; nor had [they]194-the gregara any brandy left to be [their]194-the gregara consolation , for even in the haste and secrecy of [our]1745-we departure [Andie]297-andie had managed to remove it .

It was [our]1745-we first care to set Anster ashore in [a cove by [the Glenteithy Rocks]114-the glenteithy rocks]1755-a cove by the glenteithy rocks , so that the deliverance of [[our]1745-we maroons]1756-our maroons might be duly seen to the next day . Thence [we]1745-we kept away up [Firth]99-the firth . The breeze , which was then so spirited , swiftly declined , but never wholly failed [us]1745-we . All day [we]1745-we kept moving , though often not much more ; and it was after dark ere [we]1745-we were up with [the Queensferry]57-the queensferry . To keep the letter of [Andie]297-andie s engagement or what was left of it [I]0-i must remain on board , but [I]0-i thought no harm to communicate with [the shore]1220-the shore in writing . On [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange s cover , where the Government seal must have a good deal surprised [[my]0-i correspondent]1758-my correspondent , [I]0-i writ , by [the boat]1266-the boat s lantern , a few necessary words , aboard and [Andie]297-andie carried [them]1760-them to [Rankeillor]176-rankeillor . In about an hour [he]176-rankeillor came again , with a purse of money and the assurance that a good horse should be standing saddled for [me]0-i by two to - morrow at [Clackmannan Pool]117-clackmannan pool . This done , and [the boat]1266-the boat riding by [her]1266-the boat stone anchor , [we]1745-we lay down to sleep under the sail .

[We]1745-we were in [the Pool]1762-the pool the next day long ere two ; and there was nothing left for [me]0-i but to sit and wait . [I]0-i felt little alacrity upon [my]0-i errand . [I]0-i would have been glad of any passable excuse to lay it down ; but none being to be found , [my]0-i uneasiness was no less great than if [I]0-i had been running to some desired pleasure . By shortly after one the horse was at [the waterside]1763-the waterside , and [I]0-i could see [a man]519-a man walking it to and fro till [I]0-i should land , which vastly swelled [my]0-i impatience . [Andie]297-andie ran the moment of [my]0-i liberation very fine , showing [himself]297-andie [a man of [his]297-andie bare word]1765-a man of his bare word , but scarce serving [[his]297-andie employers]1766-his employers with a heaped measure ; and by about fifty seconds after two [I]0-i was in the saddle and on the full stretch for [Stirling]56-stirling . In a little more than an hour [I]0-i had passed [that town]1767-that town , and was already mounting [Alan Water side]118-alan water side , when the weather broke in a small tempest . The rain blinded [me]0-i , the wind had nearly beat [me]0-i from the saddle , and the first darkness of the night surprised [me]0-i in [a wilderness still some way east of [Balwhidder]12-balwhidder]1768-a wilderness still some way east of balwhidder , not very sure of [my]0-i direction and mounted on a horse that began already to be weary .

In the press of [my]0-i hurry , and to be spared the delay and annoyance of [a guide]1769-a guide , [I]0-i had followed so far as it was possible for [any horseman the line of [my]0-i journey with [Alan]185-alan]1770-any horseman the line of my journey with alan . This [I]0-i did with open eyes , foreseeing a great risk in it , which the tempest had now brought to a reality . The last that [I]0-i knew of where [I]0-i was , [I]0-i think it must have been about [Uam Var]119-uam var ; the hour perhaps six at night . [I]0-i must still think it great good fortune that [I]0-i got about eleven to [my]0-i destination , [the house of [Duncan Dhu]120-duncan dhu]1771-the house of duncan dhu . Where [I]0-i had wandered in the interval perhaps the horse could tell . [I]0-i know [we]1772-we were twice down , and once over the saddle and for a moment carried away in a roaring burn . [Steed]329-steed and [rider]1773-rider were bemired up to the eyes .

From [Duncan]186-duncan [I]0-i had news of the trial . It was followed in [all these Highland regions]1774-all these highland regions with religious interest ; news of it spread from [Inverary]39-inverary as swift as [men]3421-men could travel ; and [I]0-i was rejoiced to learn that , up to a late hour that Saturday it was not yet concluded ; and [all men]1776-all men began to suppose it must spread over the Monday . Under the spur of this intelligence [I]0-i would not sit to eat ; but , [Duncan]186-duncan having agreed to be [[my]0-i guide]1777-my guide , took [the road]971-the road again on foot , with the piece in [my]0-i hand and munching as [I]0-i went . [Duncan]186-duncan brought with [him]186-duncan a flask of usquebaugh and a hand - lantern ; which last enlightened [us]1772-we just so long as [we]1772-we could find [houses where to rekindle it]1779-houses where to rekindle it , for the thing leaked outrageously and blew out with every gust . The more part of the night [we]1772-we walked blindfold among sheets of rain , and day found [us]1772-we aimless on [the mountains]784-the mountains . Hard by [we]1772-we struck a hut on [a burn - side]1781-a burn - side , where [we]1772-we got bite and a direction ; and , a little before the end of the sermon , came to [the kirk doors of [Inverary]39-inverary]1782-the kirk doors of inverary .

The rain had somewhat washed the upper parts of [me]0-i , but [I]0-i was still bogged as high as to the knees ; [I]0-i streamed water ; [I]0-i was so weary [I]0-i could hardly limp , and [my]0-i face was like a ghost s. [I]0-i stood certainly more in need of a change of raiment and a bed to lie on , than of all the benefits in Christianity . For all which being persuaded the chief point for [me]0-i was to make [myself]0-i immediately public [I]0-i set the door of [the church]1783-the church with the dirty [Duncan]186-duncan at [my]0-i tails , and finding [a vacant place]1784-a vacant place sat down .

" Thirteently , [[my]1411-the minister brethren]4031-my brethren , and in parenthesis , the law itself must be regarded as a means of grace , "[1411-the minister] [the minister]1411-the minister was saying , in the voice of one delighting to pursue an argument .

The sermon was in English on account of the assize . [The judges]1786-the judges were present with [[their]1786-the judges armed attendants]1787-their armed attendants , [the halberts]1788-the halberts glittered in a corner by the door , and the seats were thronged beyond custom with the array of [lawyers]1789-lawyers . The text was in Romans 5th and 13th [the minister]1411-the minister a skilled hand ; and the whole of that able churchful from [Argyle]330-argyle , and [[my]0-i Lords]1791-my lords [Elchies]331-elchies and [Kilkerran]332-kilkerran , down to [the halbertmen that came in [their]1786-the judges attendance]1792-the halbertmen that came in their attendance was sunk with gathered brows in a profound critical attention . [The minister]1411-the minister [himself]1411-the minister and [a sprinkling of those about the door]1794-a sprinkling of those about the door observed [our]1795-our entrance at the moment and immediately forgot the same ; [the rest]1213-the rest either did not hear or would not hear or would not be heard ; and [I]0-i sat amongst [[my]0-i friends]3075-my friends and [enemies unremarked]1798-enemies unremarked .

The first that [I]0-i singled out was [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange . [He]182-prestongrange sat well forward , like an eager horseman in the saddle , [his]182-prestongrange lips moving with relish , [his]182-prestongrange eyes glued on [the minister]1411-the minister ; the doctrine was clearly to [his]182-prestongrange mind . [Charles Stewart]199-stewart , on the other hand , was half asleep , and looked harassed and pale . As for [Simon Fraser]240-mr. simon , [he]240-mr. simon appeared like a blot , and almost a scandal , in the midst of [that attentive congregation]1800-that attentive congregation , digging [his]240-mr. simon hands in [his]240-mr. simon pockets , shifting [his]240-mr. simon legs , clearing [his]240-mr. simon throat , and rolling up [his]240-mr. simon bald eyebrows and shooting out [his]240-mr. simon eyes to right and left , now with a yawn , now with a secret smile . At times , too , [he]240-mr. simon would take the Bible in front of [him]240-mr. simon , run it through , seem to read a bit , run it through again , and stop and yawn prodigiously : the whole as if for exercise .

In the course of this restlessness [his]240-mr. simon eye alighted on [myself]0-i . [He]240-mr. simon sat a second stupefied , then tore a half - leaf out of the Bible , scrawled upon it with a pencil , and passed it with a whispered word to [[his]240-mr. simon next neighbour]1801-his next neighbour . The note came to [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange , who gave [me]0-i but the one look ; thence it voyaged to the hands of [Mr. Erskine]259-mr. erskine ; thence again to [Argyle]330-argyle , where [he]240-mr. simon sat between [the other two lords of session]1802-the other two lords of session , and [his]240-mr. simon Grace turned and fixed [me]0-i with an arrogant eye . [The last of those interested in [my]0-i presence]1803-the last of those interested in my presence was [Charlie Stewart]199-stewart , and [he]199-stewart too began to pencil and hand about dispatches , none of which [I]0-i was able to trace to [their]1804-their destination in [the crowd]1805-the crowd .

But the passage of these notes had aroused notice ; [all who were in the secret or supposed themselves to be so]1806-all who were in the secret or supposed themselves to be so were whispering information the rest questions ; and [the minister]1411-the minister [himself]1411-the minister seemed quite discountenanced by the flutter in [the church]1783-the church and sudden stir and whispering . [His]1411-the minister voice changed , [he]1411-the minister plainly faltered , nor did [he]1411-the minister again recover the easy conviction and full tones of [his]1411-the minister delivery . It would be a puzzle to [him]1411-the minister till [his]1411-the minister dying day , why a sermon that had gone with triumph through four parts , should thus miscarry in the fifth .

As for [me]0-i , [I]0-i continued to sit there , very wet and weary , and a good deal anxious as to what should happen next , but greatly exulting in [my]0-i success .

CHAPTER XVII THE MEMORIAL

The last word of the blessing was scarce out of [the minister]1411-the minister s mouth before [Stewart]199-stewart had [me]0-i by the arm . [We]1810-we were [the first to be forth of [the church]1783-the church]1811-the first to be forth of the church , and [he]1411-the minister made such extraordinary expedition that [we]1810-we were safe within the four walls of [a house]1013-a house before [the street]3016-the street had begun to be thronged with [the home - going congregation]1815-the home - going congregation .

" Am [I]0-i yet in time ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" Ay and no , "[1411-the minister] said [he]1411-the minister . " The case is over ; [the jury]3661-the jury is enclosed , and will so kind as let [us]1810-we ken [their]3661-the jury view of it to - morrow in the morning , the same as [I]1411-the minister could have told [it]3661-the jury [my]1411-the minister own self three days ago before the play began . The thing has been public from the start . The panel kent it , [Ye]0-i may do what [ye]0-i will for [me]1411-the minister , whispers [he]1411-the minister two days ago . [Ye]0-i ken [my]1411-the minister fate by what [the Duke of Argyle]3206-the duke of argyle has just said to [Mr. Macintosh]333-mr. macintosh . O , it s been a scandal ![1411-the minister]

" [The great Agyle]334-the great agyle [he]1411-the minister gaed before , [He]1411-the minister gart the cannons and guns to roar , "[1816-the very macer]

and [the very macer]1816-the very macer cried [Cruachan]122-cruachan ! But now that [I]0-i have got [you]122-cruachan again [I]0-i ll never despair . [The oak]1817-the oak shall go over the myrtle yet ; [we]1818-we ll ding [the Campbells]3209-the campbells yet in [[their]3209-the campbells [own town]1821-own town]1820-their own town . Praise [God]223-god that [I]0-i should see the day ! "[1822-his]

[He]1822-his was leaping with excitement , emptied out [his]1822-his mails upon the floor that [I]0-i might have a change of clothes , and incommoded [me]0-i with [his]1822-his assistance as [I]0-i changed . What remained to be done , or how [I]0-i was to do it , was what [he]1822-his never told [me]0-i nor , [I]0-i believe , so much as thought of . " [We]4034-we ll ding [the Campbells]204-the campbells yet ! "[1822-his] that was still [his]1822-his overcome . And it was forced home upon [my]0-i mind how this , that had the externals of a sober process of law , was in its essence a clan battle between [savage clans]1823-savage clans . [I]0-i thought [[my]0-i friend]3036-my friend [the Writer]547-the writer none of the least savage . Who that had only seen [him]1822-his at a counsel s back before [the Lord Ordinary or following a golf ball]1826-the lord ordinary or following a golf ball and laying down [his]1822-his clubs on [Bruntsfield links]123-bruntsfield links , could have recognised for [the same person]1827-the same person [this voluble and violent clansman]1828-this voluble and violent clansman ?

[[James Stewart]181-james s counsel]1829-james stewart s counsel were four in number Sheriffs [Brown of Colstoun]335-colstoun and [Miller]336-sheriff miller , [Mr. Robert Macintosh]333-mr. macintosh , and [Mr. Stewart younger of Stewart Hall]337-mr. stewart . [These]1830-these were covenanted to dine with [the Writer]547-the writer after sermon , and [I]0-i was very obligingly included of [the party]515-the party . No sooner the cloth lifted , and the first bowl very artfully compounded by [Sheriff Miller]336-sheriff miller , than [we]1833-we fell to the subject in hand . [I]0-i made a short narration of [my]0-i seizure and captivity , and was then examined and re - examined upon the circumstances of the murder . It will be remembered this was the first time [I]0-i had had [my]0-i say out , or the matter at all handled , among [lawyers]1789-lawyers ; and the consequence was very dispiriting to [the others]511-the others and [I]0-i must own disappointing to [myself]0-i .

" To sum up , "[335-colstoun] said [Colstoun]335-colstoun , " [you]4035-you prove that [Alan]185-alan was on the spot ; [you]4035-you have heard [him]185-alan proffer menaces against [Glenure]225-glenure ; and though [you]4035-you assure [us]1833-we [he]185-alan was not [the man who fired]4036-the man who fired , [you]4035-you leave a strong impression that [he]185-alan was in league with [him]185-alan , and consenting , perhaps immediately assisting , in the act . [You]4035-you show [him]185-alan besides , at the risk of [his]185-alan own liberty , actively furthering [the criminal]4037-the criminal s escape . And the rest of [your]4035-you testimony so far as the least material depends on the bare word of [Alan]185-alan or of [James]181-james , [the two accused]4038-the two accused . In short , [you]4035-you do not at all break , but only lengthen by [one personage]4039-one personage , the chain that binds [[our]1833-we client]4040-our client to [the murderer]3233-the murderer ; and [I]335-colstoun need scarcely say that the introduction of [a third accomplice]4042-a third accomplice rather aggravates that appearance of a conspiracy which has been [our]1833-we stumbling block from the beginning . "[335-colstoun]

" [I]336-sheriff miller am of the same opinion , "[336-sheriff miller] said [Sheriff Miller]336-sheriff miller . " [I]336-sheriff miller think [we]1833-we may all be very much obliged to [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange for taking [a most uncomfortable witness]4043-a most uncomfortable witness out of [our]1833-we way . And chiefly , [I]336-sheriff miller think , [Mr. Balfour]222-davie [himself]222-davie might be obliged . For [you]4035-you talk of [a third accomplice]4042-a third accomplice , but [Mr. Balfour]222-davie in [my]336-sheriff miller view has very much the appearance of a fourth . "[336-sheriff miller]

" Allow [me]181-james , [sirs]3157-sirs ! "[181-james] interposed [Stewart]181-james [the Writer]547-the writer . " There is another view . Here [we]1833-we have [a witness]4046-a witness never fash whether material or not [a witness in this cause]4047-a witness in this cause , kidnapped by [that old , lawless , bandit crew of [the Glengyle Macgregors]190-the glengyle macgregors]4048-that old , lawless , bandit crew of the glengyle macgregors , and sequestered for near upon a month in [a bourock of old ruins on [the Bass]97-the bass]4049-a bourock of old ruins on the bass . Move that and see what dirt [you]4035-you fling on the proceedings ! [Sirs]3157-sirs , this is a tale to make [the world]3073-the world ring with ! It would be strange , with such a grip as this , if [we]1833-we couldnae squeeze out a pardon for [[my]181-james client]3636-my client . "[181-james]

" And suppose [we]1833-we took up [Mr. Balfour]222-davie s cause to - morrow ? "[337-mr. stewart] said [Stewart Hall]337-mr. stewart . " [I]337-mr. stewart am much deceived or [we]1833-we should find so many impediments thrown in [our]1833-we path , as that [James]181-james should have been hanged before [we]1833-we had found a court to hear [us]1833-we . This is a great scandal , but [I]337-mr. stewart suppose [we]1833-we have [none of [us]1833-we]4053-none of us forgot a greater still , [I]337-mr. stewart mean the matter of [the Lady Grange]267-the lady grange . [The woman]4054-the woman was still in [durance]124-durance ; [[my]337-mr. stewart friend]3036-my friend [Mr. Hope of Rankeillor]176-rankeillor did what was humanly possible ; and how did [he]176-rankeillor speed ? [He]176-rankeillor never got a warrant ! Well , it ll be the same now ; the same weapons will be used . This is a scene , [gentleman , of clan animosity]4056-gentleman , of clan animosity . The hatred of the name which [I]337-mr. stewart have the honour to bear , rages in high quarters . There is nothing here to be viewed but naked [Campbell]251-mrs. campbell spite and scurvy Campbell intrigue . "[337-mr. stewart]

[You]1837-you may be sure this was to touch a welcome topic , and [I]0-i sat for some time in the midst of [my]0-i learned counsel , almost deaved with [their]1838-their talk but extremely little the wiser for its purport . [The Writer]547-the writer was led into some hot expressions ; [Colstoun]335-colstoun must take [him]547-the writer up and set [him]547-the writer right ; [the rest joined in on different sides]1840-the rest joined in on different sides , but all pretty noisy ; [the Duke of [Argyle]330-argyle]3206-the duke of argyle was beaten like a blanket ; [King George]208-king george came in for a few digs in the by - going and a great deal of rather elaborate defence ; and there was only [one person that seemed to be forgotten]1842-one person that seemed to be forgotten , and that was [[James]181-james of [the Glens]48-the glens]3602-james of the glens .

Through all this [Mr. Miller]338-mr. miller sat quiet . [He]338-mr. miller was a slip of [an oldish gentleman , ruddy and twinkling]1844-an oldish gentleman , ruddy and twinkling ; [he]338-mr. miller spoke in a smooth rich voice , with an infinite effect of pawkiness , dealing out each word the way [an actor]1845-an actor does , to give the most expression possible ; and even now , when [he]338-mr. miller was silent , and sat there with [his]338-mr. miller wig laid aside , [his]338-mr. miller glass in both hands , [his]338-mr. miller mouth funnily pursed , and [his]338-mr. miller chin out , [he]338-mr. miller seemed the mere picture of a merry slyness . It was plain [he]338-mr. miller had a word to say , and waited for the fit occasion .

It came presently . [Colstoun]335-colstoun had wound up one of [his]335-colstoun speeches with some expression of [their]1846-their duty to [[their]1846-their client]1847-their client . [[His]335-colstoun brother]2976-his brother sheriff was pleased , [I]0-i suppose , with the transition . [He]2976-his brother took the table in [his]2976-his brother confidence with a gesture and a look .

" That suggests to [me]2976-his brother a consideration which seems overlooked , "[2976-his brother] said [he]2976-his brother . " The interest of [[our]1846-their client]4040-our client goes certainly before all , but [the world]3073-the world does not come to an end with [James Stewart]181-james . "[2976-his brother] Whereat [he]2976-his brother cocked [his]2976-his brother eye . " [I]2976-his brother might condescend , exempli gratia , upon a [Mr. George Brown]339-mr. george brown , a [Mr. Thomas Miller]338-mr. miller , and a [Mr. David Balfour]222-davie . [Mr. David Balfour]222-davie has a very good ground of complaint , and [I]2976-his brother think , [gentlemen]3557-gentlemen if [his]222-davie story was properly redd out [I]2976-his brother think there would be a number of wigs on the green . "[2976-his brother]

The whole table turned to [him]2976-his brother with a common movement .

" Properly handled and carefully redd out , [his]4060-his is a story that could scarcely fail to have some consequence , "[2976-his brother] [he]2976-his brother continued . " The whole administration of justice , from [its highest officer]4061-its highest officer downward , would be totally discredited ; and it looks to [me]2976-his brother as if [they]1849-they would need to be replaced . "[2976-his brother] [He]2976-his brother seemed to shine with cunning as [he]2976-his brother said it . " And [I]2976-his brother need not point out to [ye]4062-ye that this of [Mr. Balfour]222-davie s would be a remarkable bonny cause to appear in , "[2976-his brother] [he]2976-his brother added .

Well , there [they]1849-they all were started on [another hare]1850-another hare ; [Mr. Balfour]222-davie s cause , and what kind of speeches could be there delivered , and what [officials]1851-officials could be thus turned out , and who would succeed to [their]1851-officials positions . [I]0-i shall give but the two specimens . It was proposed to approach [Simon Fraser]240-mr. simon , whose testimony , if it could be obtained , would prove certainly fatal to [Argyle]330-argyle and to [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange . [Miller]338-mr. miller highly approved of the attempt . " [We]4063-us have here before [us]4063-us a dreeping roast , "[338-mr. miller] said [he]338-mr. miller , " here is cut - and - come - again for all . "[338-mr. miller] And methought all licked [their]1849-they lips . [The other]3003-the other was already near the end . [Stewart]181-james [the Writer]547-the writer was out of the body with delight , smelling vengeance on [[his]181-james chief enemy]1854-his chief enemy , [the Duke]3273-the duke .

" [Gentlemen]3557-gentlemen , "[181-james] cried [he]181-james , charging [his]181-james glass , " here is to [Sheriff Miller]336-sheriff miller . [His]181-james legal abilities are known to all . [[His]181-james culinary]4065-his culinary , this bowl in front of [us]4063-us is here to speak for . But when it comes to the poleetical ! "[181-james] cries [he]181-james , and drains the glass .

" Ay , but it will hardly prove politics in [your]181-james meaning , [[my]336-sheriff miller friend]3036-my friend , "[336-sheriff miller] said the gratified [Miller]336-sheriff miller . " A revolution , if [you]181-james like , and [I]336-sheriff miller think [I]336-sheriff miller can promise [you]181-james that [historical writers]4067-historical writers shall date from [Mr. Balfour]222-davie s cause . But properly guided , [Mr. Stewart]337-mr. stewart , tenderly guided , it shall prove a peaceful revolution . "[336-sheriff miller]

" And if [the damned Campbells]4068-the damned campbells get [their]4068-the damned campbells ears rubbed , what care [I]337-mr. stewart ? "[337-mr. stewart] cries [Stewart]337-mr. stewart , smiting down [his]337-mr. stewart fist .

Methought [I]0-i was a good deal sacrificed , and rather represented in the light of [a firebrand of a fellow whom [[my]0-i cloud of lawyers]1866-my cloud of lawyers had restrained with difficulty from extremes]1865-a firebrand of a fellow whom my cloud of lawyers had restrained with difficulty from extremes . Often enough already in [our]1881-our brief relations [this gentleman]3583-this gentleman had caused [my]0-i head to spin ; no doubt but what for a moment [he]3583-this gentleman did so again now . " [I]0-i am more than willing , [I]0-i am earnestly desirous to meet [your]0-i wishes , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " It is [my]0-i design to be called to [the Bar]4082-the bar , where [your]0-i lordship s countenance would be invaluable ; and [I]0-i am besides sincerely grateful to [yourself]0-i and [family]2959-family for different marks of interest and of indulgence . " [I]1891-i will tell [you]0-i , "[1891-i] [he]1891-i presently resumed , " there is no question of [James Stewart]181-james , for or against , [James]181-james is [a dead man]4130-a dead man ; [his]181-james life is given and taken bought if [you]0-i like it better and sold ; no memorial can help no defalcation of [a faithful Mr. David]4131-a faithful mr. david hurt [him]181-james . Blow high , blow low , there will be no pardon for [James Stewart]181-james : and take that for said ! The question is now of [myself]1891-i : am [I]1891-i to stand or fall ? and [I]1891-i do not deny to [you]0-i that [I]1891-i am in some danger . But will [Mr. David Balfour]222-davie consider why ? It is not because [I]1891-i pushed the case unduly against [James]181-james ; for that , [I]1891-i am sure of condonation . And it is not because [I]1891-i have sequestered [Mr. David]222-davie on a rock , though it will pass under that colour ; but because [I]1891-i did not take the ready and plain path , to which [I]1891-i was pressed repeatedly , and send [Mr. David]222-davie to [his]222-davie grave or to the gallows . Hence the scandal hence this damned memorial , "[1891-i] striking the paper on [his]1892-he leg . " [My]1891-i tenderness for [you]0-i has brought [me]1891-i in this difficulty . [I]1891-i wish to know if [your]0-i tenderness to [your]0-i own conscience is too great to let [you]0-i help [me]1891-i out of it . "[1891-i]

No doubt but there was much of the truth in what [he]1892-he said ; if [James]181-james was past helping , whom was it more natural that [I]0-i should turn to help than just [the man before [me]0-i]1893-the man before me , who had helped [myself]0-i so often , and was even now setting [me]0-i a pattern of patience ? [I]0-i was besides not only weary , but beginning to be ashamed , of [my]0-i perpetual attitude of suspicion and refusal .

" If [you]1892-he will name the time and place , [I]1892-he will be punctually ready to attend [[your]1892-he lordship]3164-your lordship , "[1892-he] said I.

[He]1892-he shook hands with [me]0-i . " And [I]1892-he think [[my]1892-he misses]3427-my misses have some news for [you]0-i , "[1892-he] says [he]1892-he , dismissing [me]0-i .

[I]0-i came away , vastly pleased to have [my]0-i peace made , yet a little concerned in conscience ; nor could [I]0-i help wondering , as [I]0-i went back , whether , perhaps , [I]0-i had not been a scruple too good - natured .
