CHAPTER XVIII [THE TEE D BALL]1900-the tee d ball

On the morrow , from [the justices private room]1901-the justices private room , where [none]1861-none could see [me]0-i , [I]0-i heard the verdict given in and judgment rendered upon [James]181-james . [The Duke]3273-the duke s words [I]0-i am quite sure [I]0-i have correctly ; and since that famous passage has been made a subject of dispute , [I]0-i may as well commemorate [my]0-i version . Having referred to the year 45 , [the chief of [the Campbells]204-the campbells]1904-the chief of the campbells , sitting as [Justice - General upon the bench]1905-justice - general upon the bench , thus addressed [the unfortunate [Stewart]181-james before [him]1904-the chief of the campbells]1906-the unfortunate stewart before him : " If [you]181-james had been successful in that rebellion , [you]181-james might have been giving the law where [you]181-james have now received the judgment of it ; [we]4134-we , who are this day [[your]181-james judges]4135-your judges , might have been tried before one of [[your]181-james mock courts of judicature]4136-your mock courts of judicature ; and then [you]181-james might have been satiated with the blood of any name or clan to which [you]181-james had an aversion . "[181-james]

" This is to let the cat out of the bag , indeed , "[0-i] thought [I.]0-i And that was the general impression . It was extraordinary how [the young advocate lads]1907-the young advocate lads took hold and made a mock of this speech , and how scarce a meal passed but what [someone]1908-someone would get in the words : " And then [you]181-james might have been satiated . "[1908-someone] Many songs were made in time for the hour s diversion , and are near all forgot . [I]0-i remember one began :

[James]181-james was as fairly murdered as though [the Duke]3273-the duke had got a fowling - piece and stalked [him]181-james . [One witness]1920-one witness was never called . This testimony it was highly desirable to bring to the notice of [the jury]3661-the jury , without exposing [the man]3029-the man [himself]3029-the man to the perils of cross - examination ; and the way it was brought about was a matter of surprise to all . This was counted a most insidious device ; and that the name of [James More]181-james should be mingled up with it filled [me]0-i with shame for [Catriona]189-catriona and concern for [myself]0-i .

" This might have been reached in fewer words , "[182-prestongrange] says [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange grimly . " It is easy , and it is at times gracious , to say a plain Scots ay . "[182-prestongrange]

" Ah , but , [[my]1956-you lord]3161-my lord , [I]1956-you think [ye]1955-ye take [me]1956-you not yet entirely ! [He]1957-i was a minute serious , then smiled . "[1957-i]

" Perhaps not just entirely in the same direction though , [[my]1958-my lord]3161-my lord ! "[1958-my] says [I.]1958-my

" And [you]0-i shall have the last word , too ! "[1959-he] cries [he]1959-he gaily .

Indeed , [he]1959-he had some cause for gaiety , having now found the means to gain [his]1959-he purpose . To lessen the weight of the memorial , or to have a readier answer at [his]1959-he hand , [he]1959-he desired [I]0-i should appear publicly in the character of [[his]1959-he intimate]1960-his intimate . But if [I]0-i were to appear with the same publicity as a visitor to [Catriona]189-catriona in [[her]189-catriona prison]4213-her prison [the world]3073-the world would scarce stint to draw conclusions , and the true nature of [James]181-james More s escape must become evident to all . This was the little problem [I]0-i had to set [him]1959-he of a sudden , and to which [he]1959-he had so briskly found an answer . [I]0-i was to be tethered in [Glasgow]125-glasgow by that job of copying , which in mere outward decency [I]0-i could not well refuse ; and during these hours of employment [Catriona]189-catriona was privately got rid of . [I]0-i think shame to write of [this man that loaded [me]0-i with so many goodnesses]1963-this man that loaded me with so many goodnesses . CHAPTER XIX [I]0-i AM MUCH IN THE HANDS OF THE LADIES

The copying was a weary business , the more so as [I]0-i perceived very early there was no sort of urgency in the matters treated , and began very early to consider [my]0-i employment a pretext . [I]0-i had no sooner finished than [I]0-i got to horse , used what remained of daylight to the best purpose , and being at last fairly benighted , slept in [a house by [Almond - Water]129-almond - water side]1965-a house by almond - water side . [I]0-i was in the saddle again before the day , and the [Edinburgh]10-edinburgh booths were just opening when [I]0-i clattered in by [the West Bow]130-the west bow and drew up a smoking horse at [[my]0-i lord]3161-my lord Advocate s door . CHAPTER XX [I]0-i CONTINUE TO MOVE IN GOOD SOCIETY

For about exactly two months [I]0-i remained [a guest in [[Prestongrange]182-prestongrange s family]1990-prestongrange s family , where [I]0-i bettered [my]0-i acquaintance with the bench , the bar , and the flower of [[Edinburgh]10-edinburgh company]1991-edinburgh company]1989-a guest in prestongrange s family , where i bettered my acquaintance with the bench , the bar , and the flower of edinburgh company . [You]1992-you are not to suppose [my]0-i education was neglected ; on the contrary , [I]0-i was kept extremely busy . [I]0-i studied the French , so as to be more prepared to go to [Leyden]74-leyden ; [I]0-i set [myself]0-i to the fencing , and wrought hard , sometimes three hours in the day , with notable advancement ; at the suggestion of [[my]0-i cousin]3098-my cousin , [Pilrig]180-mr. balfour , who was [an apt musician]1994-an apt musician , [I]0-i was put to a singing class ; and by the orders of [[my]0-i Miss Grant]1995-my miss grant , to one for the dancing , at which [I]0-i must say [I]0-i proved far from ornamental . However , all were good enough to say it gave [me]0-i an address a little more genteel ; and there is no question but [I]0-i learned to manage [my]0-i coat skirts and sword with more dexterity , and to stand in [a room]1996-a room as though the same belonged to [me]0-i . [My]0-i clothes themselves were all earnestly re - ordered ; and the most trifling circumstance , such as where [I]0-i should tie [my]0-i hair , or the colour of [my]0-i ribbon , debated among [the three misses]1997-the three misses like a thing of weight . One way with another , no doubt [I]0-i was a good deal improved to look at , and acquired a bit of modest air that would have surprised [the good folks at [Essendean]30-essendean]1998-the good folks at essendean .

[The two younger misses]924-the two younger misses were very willing to discuss a point of [my]0-i habiliment , because that was in the line of [their]924-the two younger misses chief thoughts . [I]0-i can not say that [they]924-the two younger misses appeared any other way conscious of [my]0-i presence ; and though always more than civil , with a kind of heartless cordiality , could not hide how much [I]0-i wearied [them]924-the two younger misses . As for [the aunt]739-the aunt , [she]739-the aunt was [a wonderful still woman]2001-a wonderful still woman ; and [I]0-i think [she]739-the aunt gave [me]0-i much the same attention as [she]739-the aunt gave the rest of [the family]770-the family , which was little enough . [The eldest daughter]2003-the eldest daughter and [the Advocate]2990-the advocate [himself]2990-the advocate were thus [[my]0-i principal friends]2005-my principal friends , and [our]2006-we familiarity was much increased by a pleasure that [we]2006-we took in common . Before the court met [we]2006-we spent a day or two at [the house of [Grange]131-grange]2007-the house of grange , living very nobly with an open table , and here it was that [[we]2006-we three]2008-we three began to ride out together in [the fields]2009-the fields , a practice afterwards maintained in [Edinburgh]10-edinburgh , so far as [the Advocate]2990-the advocate s continual affairs permitted . When [we]2006-we were put in a good frame by the briskness of the exercise , the difficulties of the way , or the accidents of bad weather , [my]0-i shyness wore entirely off ; [we]2006-we forgot that [we]2006-we were [strangers]2950-strangers , and speech not being required , it flowed the more naturally on . Then it was that [they]2012-they had [my]0-i story from [me]0-i , bit by bit , from the time that [I]0-i left [Essendean]30-essendean , with [my]0-i voyage and battle in [the Covenant]132-the covenant , wanderings in [the heather]2013-the heather , etc . ; and from the interest [they]2012-they found in [my]0-i adventures sprung the circumstance of a jaunt [we]2006-we made a little later on , on a day when [the courts]2014-the courts were not sitting , and of which [I]0-i will tell a trifle more at length .

[We]2006-we took horse early , and passed first by [the house of [Shaws]222-davie]3074-the house of shaws , where [it]3074-the house of shaws stood smokeless in a great field of white frost , for it was yet early in the day . Here [Prestongrange]182-prestongrange alighted down , gave [me]0-i [his]182-prestongrange horse , an proceeded alone to visit [[my]0-i uncle]3436-my uncle . [My]0-i heart , [I]0-i remember , swelled up bitter within [me]0-i at the sight of [that bare house]2017-that bare house and the thought of [the old miser]2018-the old miser sitting chittering within in [the cold kitchen]2019-the cold kitchen !

" There is [[my]0-i home]414-my home , "[0-i] said [I]0-i ; " and [[my]0-i family]3425-my family . "[0-i]

" [Poor David Balfour]222-davie ! "[234-miss grant] said [Miss Grant]234-miss grant .

" [I]0-i will never pretend sorrow , "[0-i] said [I]0-i ; and , to say the truth , during [his]182-prestongrange absence [Miss Grant]234-miss grant and [I]0-i had been embellishing [the place]490-the place in fancy with [plantations]2021-plantations , parterres , and a terrace much as [I]0-i have since carried out in fact .

For a good while [I]0-i heard nothing further of [Catriona]189-catriona [[my]0-i Miss]2040-my miss [Grant]234-miss grant remaining quite impenetrable , and stopping [my]0-i mouth with pleasantries . [She]3012-the young lady seemed indeed like the very spirit of mischief , and , walking briskly in [the room]693-the room , had soon involved [me]0-i in a kind of quarrel over nothing and at the least with nothing intended on [my]0-i side . [I]0-i was like [Christian]356-christian in [the slough]2042-the slough the more [I]0-i tried to clamber out upon the side , the deeper [I]0-i became involved ; until at last [I]0-i heard [her]3012-the young lady declare , with a great deal of passion , that [she]3012-the young lady would take that answer from the hands of [none]1861-none , and [I]0-i must down upon [my]0-i knees for pardon .

The billet had neither place nor date . " [Dear Mr. David]222-davie , "[3012-the young lady] it began , " [I]3012-the young lady get [your]0-i news continually by [[my]3012-the young lady cousin]3098-my cousin , [Miss Grant]234-miss grant , and it is a pleisand hearing . For , upon a retrospect , it appeared [I]0-i had not done so grandly , after all ; but with the greatest possible amount of big speech and preparation , had accomplished nothing .

PART II [FATHER]2978-father AND [DAUGHTER]2119-daughter

CHAPTER XXI THE VOYAGE INTO [HOLLAND]75-holland

[The ship]3120-the ship lay at a single anchor , well outside [the pier of [Leith]49-leith]2121-the pier of leith , so that [all [we]2116-we [passengers]2123-passengers]2122-all we passengers must come to [it]3120-the ship by the means of skiffs . This was very little troublesome , for the reason that the day was a flat calm , very frosty and cloudy , and with a low shifting fog upon [the water]3088-the water . The body of [the vessel]2125-the vessel was thus quite hid as [I]0-i drew near , but the tall spars of [her]2125-the vessel stood high and bright in a sunshine like the flickering of a fire . [She]2125-the vessel proved to be [a very roomy , commodious merchant]2126-a very roomy , commodious merchant , but somewhat blunt in the bows , and loaden extraordinary deep with salt , salted salmon , and fine white linen stockings for [the Dutch]281-the dutch . Upon [my]0-i coming on board , [the captain]3428-the captain welcomed [me]0-i one Sang out of [Lesmahago]136-lesmahago , [I]0-i believe , a very hearty , friendly tarpaulin of [a man]519-a man , but at the moment in rather of a bustle . There had [no other of [the passengers]2130-the passengers]2129-no other of the passengers yet appeared , so that [I]0-i was left to walk about upon [the deck]1250-the deck , viewing the prospect and wondering a good deal what these farewells should be which [I]0-i was promised .

All [Edinburgh]10-edinburgh and [the Pentland Hills]137-the pentland hills glinted above [me]0-i in a kind of smuisty brightness , now and again overcome with blots of cloud ; of Leith there was no more than the tops of chimneys visible , and on the face of [the water]3088-the water , where the haar 24 lay , nothing at all . Out of this [I]0-i was presently aware of a sound of oars pulling , and a little after as if out of the smoke of a fire [a boat]1439-a boat issued . There sat [a grave man in the stern sheets , well muffled from the cold]2134-a grave man in the stern sheets , well muffled from the cold , and by [his]2134-a grave man in the stern sheets , well muffled from the cold side [a tall , pretty , tender figure of a maid that brought [my]0-i heart]2135-a tall , pretty , tender figure of a maid that brought my heart to a stand . [I]0-i had scarce the time to catch [my]0-i breath in , and be ready to meet [her]2136-she , as [she]2136-she stepped upon [the deck]1250-the deck , smiling , and making [my]0-i best bow , which was now vastly finer than some months before , when first [I]0-i made it to [[her]2136-she ladyship]2138-her ladyship . No doubt [we]2139-we were both a good deal changed : [she]2136-she seemed to have shot up like [a young , comely tree]2140-a young , comely tree . [She]2136-she had now a kind of pretty backwardness that became [her]2136-she well as of one that regarded [herself]2136-she more highly and was [fairly woman]2141-fairly woman ; and for another thing , the hand of [the same magician]2142-the same magician had been at work upon [the pair of [us]2139-we]1062-the pair of us , and [Miss Grant]234-miss grant had made [us]2139-we both braw , if [she]234-miss grant could make but [the one bonny]2144-the one bonny .

The same cry , in words not very different , came from both of [us]2139-we , that [the other]3003-the other was come in compliment to say farewell , and then [we]2139-we perceived in a flash [we]2139-we were to ship together .

" O , why will not [Baby]361-baby have been telling [me]2136-she ! "[2136-she] [she]2136-she cried ; and then remembered a letter [she]2136-she had been given , on the condition of not opening it till [she]2136-she was well on board . [Within]362-within was an enclosure for [myself]0-i , and ran thus :

" [[Your]363-dear davie affectionate friend]4334-your affectionate friend and [governess]4357-governess , "[234-miss grant] [Barbara Grant]234-miss grant . "[234-miss grant]

" [Catriona]189-catriona ? "[0-i] said [I.]0-i It seemed that was the first and last word of [my]0-i eloquence .

Let [us]2152-we never speak more , [we]2152-we two , of pardon or offence . "[0-i]

[We]2152-we stood after that silent , [Catriona]189-catriona looking on the deck and [I]0-i on [her]189-catriona ; and before there was more speech , a little wind having sprung up in the nor -west , [they]2153-they began to shake out the sails and heave in upon the anchor .

[Mrs. Gebbie]364-mrs. gebbie for that was [her]364-mrs. gebbie name was by great good fortune heavily incommoded by [the sea]1224-the sea , and lay day and night on the broad of [her]364-mrs. gebbie back . [We]2152-we were besides [the only creatures at [all young on board the Rose]2164-all young on board the rose]2163-the only creatures at all young on board the rose , except [a white - faced boy that did [my]0-i old duty to attend upon the table]2165-a white - faced boy that did my old duty to attend upon the table ; and it came about that [Catriona]189-catriona and [I]0-i were left almost entirely to [ourselves]2152-we . [We]2152-we had the next seats together at the table , where [I]0-i waited on [her]189-catriona with extraordinary pleasure . On [deck]2166-deck , [I]0-i made [her]189-catriona a soft place with [my]0-i cloak ; and the weather being singularly fine for that season , with bright frosty days and nights , a steady , gentle wind , and scarce a sheet started all the way through [the North Sea]104-the north sea , [we]2152-we sat there only now and again walking to and fro for warmth from the first blink of the sun till eight or nine at night under the clear stars . [The merchants]2167-the merchants or [Captain Sang]365-captain sang would sometimes glance and smile upon [us]2152-we , or pass a merry word or two and give [us]2152-we the go - by again ; but the most part of the time [they]2168-they were deep in herring and chintzes and linen , or in computations of the slowness of the passage , and left [us]2152-we to [our]2152-we own concerns , which were very little important to any but [ourselves]2152-we .

At the first , [we]2152-we had a great deal to say , and thought [ourselves]2152-we pretty witty ; and [I]0-i was at a little pains to be [the beau]2169-the beau , and [she]189-catriona [I]0-i believe to play [the young lady of experience]2170-the young lady of experience . But soon [we]2152-we grew plainer with [each other]2951-each other . [I]0-i laid aside [my]0-i high , clipped English what little there was left of it and forgot to make [my]0-i Edinburgh bows and scrapes ; [she]189-catriona , upon [her]189-catriona side , fell into a sort of kind familiarity ; and [we]2152-we dwelt together like those of [the same household]2172-the same household , only upon [my]0-i side with a more deep emotion . About the same time the bottom seemed to fall out of [our]2152-we conversation , and neither one of [us]2152-we the less pleased . Whiles [she]189-catriona would tell [me]0-i old wives tales , of which [she]189-catriona had a wonderful variety , many of them from [[my]0-i friend red - headed [Niel]366-niel]2173-my friend red - headed niel . [She]189-catriona told [them]2174-them very pretty , and they were pretty enough childish tales ; but the pleasure to [myself]0-i was in the sound of [her]189-catriona voice , and the thought that [she]189-catriona was telling and [I]0-i listening . Whiles , again , [we]2152-we would sit entirely silent , not communicating even with a look , and tasting pleasure enough in the sweetness of that neighbourhood . [I]0-i speak here only for [myself]0-i . Of what was in [the maid]534-the maid s mind , [I]0-i am not very sure that ever [I]0-i asked [myself]0-i ; and what was in [my]0-i own , [I]0-i was afraid to consider . [I]0-i need make no secret of it now , either to [myself]0-i or to [the reader]2176-the reader ; [I]0-i was fallen totally in love . [She]534-the maid came between [me]0-i and the sun . [She]534-the maid had grown suddenly taller , as [I]0-i say , but with a wholesome growth ; [she]534-the maid seemed all health , and lightness , and brave spirits ; and [I]0-i thought [she]534-the maid walked like a young deer , and stood like a birch upon [the mountains]784-the mountains . It was enough for [me]0-i to sit near by [her]534-the maid on [the deck]1250-the deck ; and [I]0-i declare [I]0-i scarce spent two thoughts upon the future , and was so well content with what [I]0-i then enjoyed that [I]0-i was never at the pains to imagine any further step ; unless perhaps that [I]0-i would be sometimes tempted to take [her]534-the maid hand in [mine]0-i and hold it there . But [I]0-i was too like a miser of what joys [I]0-i had , and would venture nothing on a hazard .

What [we]2179-we spoke was usually of [ourselves]2179-we or of [each other]2951-each other , so that if [anyone]3224-anyone had been at so much pains as overhear [us]2179-we , [he]3224-anyone must have supposed [us]2179-we [the most egotistical persons in [the world]3073-the world]2182-the most egotistical persons in the world . It befell one day when [we]2179-we were at this practice , that [we]2179-we came on a discourse of [friends]444-friends and friendship , and [I]0-i think now that [we]2179-we were sailing near the wind . [We]2179-we said what a fine thing friendship was , and how little [we]2179-we had guessed of it , and how it made life a new thing , and a thousand covered things of the same kind that will have been said , since the foundation of [the world]3073-the world , by [young folk in the same predicament]2186-young folk in the same predicament . Then [we]2179-we remarked upon the strangeness of that circumstance , that [friends]444-friends came together in the beginning as if [they]444-friends were there for the first time , and yet [each]2188-each had been alive a good while , losing time with [other people]2189-other people .

" It is not much that [I]2190-i have done , "[2190-i] said [she]2190-i , " and [I]2190-i could be telling [you]4396-you the five - fifths of it in two - three words . It is only [a girl]504-a girl [I]2190-i am , and what can befall [a girl]504-a girl , at all events ? But [I]2190-i went with [the clan]3092-the clan in the year 45 . [The men]3722-the men marched with swords and fire - locks , and some of [them]3722-the men in brigades in the same set of tartan ; [they]3722-the men were not backward at the marching , [I]2190-i can tell [you]4396-you . [I]0-i was in that state of subjection to the thought of [[my]0-i friend]3036-my friend that it mattered not what [I]0-i did , nor scarce whether [I]0-i was in [her]3036-my friend presence or out of it ; [I]0-i had caught [her]3036-my friend like some kind of a noble fever that lived continually in [my]0-i bosom , by night and by day , and whether [I]0-i was waking or asleep . So it befell that after [I]0-i was come into the fore - part of [the ship]3120-the ship where the broad bows splashed into the billows , [I]0-i was in no such hurry to return as [you]2203-you might fancy ; rather prolonged [my]0-i absence like a variety in pleasure .
